Text

[Poets of all ages and of all denominations]237-poets of all ages and of all denominations are unanimous in assuring [us]238-we that there was once a period on [this grey earth]239-this grey earth known as the Golden Age . These irresponsible hards describe it in terms of the vaguest , most poetic splendour , and , apart from the fact , upon which [they]237-poets of all ages and of all denominations are all agreed , that the weather was always perfectly charming , [we]238-we have to reconstruct its characteristics in the main for [ourselves]238-we . Perhaps if the weather was uniformly delightful , even in this nineteenth century , the golden age might return again . [We]238-we all know how perceptibly [our]238-we physical , mental and spiritual level is raised by a few days of really charming weather ; but until the weather determines to be always golden , [we]238-we can hardly expect it of the age . Yet even now , even in [England]1-england , and even in [London]2-london , [we]238-we have every year a few days which must surely be waifs and strays from the golden age , days which have fluttered down from under the hands of [the recording angel]240-the recording angel , as [he]240-the recording angel tied up [his]240-the recording angel reports , and , after floating about for years in [dim , interplanetary space]241-dim , interplanetary space , sometimes drop down upon [us]238-we . [They]242-they may last a week , [they]242-they have been known to last a fortnight ; again , [they]242-they may curtail [themselves]242-they into a few hours , but they are never wholly absent . At the time at which this story opens , [London]2-london was having [its]2-london annual golden days ; days to be associated with cool , early rides in the crumbly Row , with sitting on small , green chairs beneath the trees at [the corner of [the Park]244-the park]243-the corner of the park ; with a general disinclination to exert [oneself]245-oneself , or to stop smoking cigarettes ; with a temper distinctly above its normal level , and a corresponding absence of moods . The crudeness of spring had disappeared , but not its freshness ; the warmth of the summer had come , but not its sultriness ; the winter was definitely over and past , and even in [Hyde Park]3-hyde park the voice of the singing bird was heard , and [an old gentleman , who shall be nameless]246-an old gentleman , who shall be nameless , had committed [his]246-an old gentleman , who shall be nameless annual perjury by asserting in the Morning Post that [he]246-an old gentleman , who shall be nameless had heard a nightingale in the elm - trees by [the Ladies ' Mile]4-the ladies ' mile , which was manifestly impossible . The sky was blue ; the trees , strange to say , were green , for the leaves were out , and even the powers of soot which hover round [London]2-london had not yet had time to shed their blackening dew upon them . The season was in full swing , but [nobody]247-nobody was tired of it yet , and " all [London]2-london "[247-nobody] evinced a tendency to modified rural habits , which expressed themselves in the way of driving down to [Hurlingham]5-hurlingham , and giving water parties at [Richmond]6-richmond . To state this more shortly , it was a balmy , breezy day towards the middle of June . The shady walks that line [the side of [the Row]249-the row]248-the side of the row were full of [the usual crowds of leisurely , well - dressed people who constitute what is known as [London]2-london]250-the usual crowds of leisurely , well - dressed people who constitute what is known as london . [Anyone acquainted with that august and splendid body]251-anyone acquainted with that august and splendid body would have seen at once that something had happened ; not a famine in [China]7-china , nor a railway accident , nor a revolution , nor a war , but emphatically " something . "[252-the larger half of london] Conversation was a thing that made time pass , not a way of passing the time . Obviously [the larger half of [London]2-london]252-the larger half of london was asking questions , and the smaller half was enjoying its superiority , in being able to give answers . These indications are as clear to the practised eye as the signs of the weather appear to be to the prophet [Zadkiel]76-zadkiel . To [the amateur]253-the amateur one cloud looks much like another cloud : [the prophet]254-the prophet , on the other hand , lays a professional finger on one and says " Thunder , "[254-the prophet] while the lurid bastion , which seems fraught with fire and tempest to [the amateur]253-the amateur , is dismissed with the wave of a contemptuous hand . [A tall , young man]256-a tall , young man was slowly making [his]256-a tall , young man way across [the road]257-the road from [the arch]258-the arch . [He]256-a tall , young man was a fair specimen of " the exhausted seedlings of [our]2011-our effete aristocracy"‚Äîlong[256-a tall , young man] - limbed , clean - shaven , about six feet two high , and altogether very pleasant to look upon . [He]256-a tall , young man wore an air of extreme leisure and freedom from the smallest touch of care or anxiety , and it was quite clear that such was [his]256-a tall , young man normal atmosphere . [He]256-a tall , young man waited with serene patience for [a large number of well - appointed carriages]259-a large number of well - appointed carriages to go past , and then found [himself]256-a tall , young man blocked by another stream going in the opposite direction . However , all things come to an end , even the impossibility of crossing from the arch at the entrance of [the Park]244-the park to the trees on a fine morning in June , and on this particular morning [I]0-i have to record no exception to the rule . A horse bolting on to the Row narrowly missed knocking [him]256-a tall , young man down , and [he]256-a tall , young man looked up with mild reproach at [its rider]261-its rider , as [he]256-a tall , young man disappeared in a shower of dust and soft earth . [This young gentleman]262-this young gentleman , who has been making [his]256-a tall , young man slow and somewhat graceful entrance on to [our]263-our stage , was emphatically " [London]2-london , "[256-a tall , young man] and [he]256-a tall , young man too saw at once that something had happened . [He]256-a tall , young man looked about for [an acquaintance]264-an acquaintance , and then dropped in a leisurely manner into a chair by [his]256-a tall , young man side . " Morning , [Bertie]77-bertie , "[256-a tall , young man] [he]256-a tall , young man remarked ; " what 's up ? "[256-a tall , young man] [Bertie]77-bertie was not going to be hurried . " [Jack]78-jack spoke dreamily , as if [he]78-jack was thinking of something else . It was [his]78-jack way not to blaze abroad anything that affected [him]78-jack deeply . " [Jack]78-jack went [home]282-home meditating rather bitterly on things in general . [He]78-jack had a sense that [Fate]88-fate was not behaving very prettily to [him]78-jack . [She]88-fate had dealt [him]78-jack rather a severe blow in April last , which had knocked [him]78-jack down , and , having knocked [him]78-jack down , [she]88-fate now proceeded in a most unsportsmanlike way to kick [him]78-jack . [Jack]78-jack had a great idea of fair play , and [Fate]88-fate certainly was not playing fair . [He]78-jack would have liked to have a few words with [her]88-fate on the subject . [The world]321-the world had been very kind on the whole to [him]78-jack . [He]78-jack had always been popular , and [his]78-jack life , though perhaps rather aimless , was at least enjoyable . And since [the world]321-the world had been kind to [him]78-jack , [he]78-jack was generous to [the world]321-the world in general , and to [[his]78-jack friends]2035-his friends in particular . It had always held a high opinion of [him]78-jack , as [a thoroughly healthy - minded and pleasant companion]2036-a thoroughly healthy - minded and pleasant companion , and [he]78-jack was disposed to hold a similar opinion of it . Consequently , when [Dodo]79-dodo had refused [him]78-jack that spring , [he]78-jack had not thought badly of [her]79-dodo . [He]78-jack did not blame [her]79-dodo , or get bitter about it ; but though [he]78-jack had flattered [himself]78-jack that [he]78-jack was used to [Dodo]79-dodo 's ways , and had always recognised [her]79-dodo capabilities in the way of surprising [[her]79-dodo friends]2037-her friends , [he]78-jack had not been quite prepared for the news of [her]79-dodo engagement . In fact , [he]78-jack was surprised , and also rather resentful , chiefly against the general management of mundane affairs , but partly also against [Dodo]79-dodo [herself]79-dodo . [Dodo]79-dodo had not told [him]78-jack of [her]79-dodo engagement ; [he]78-jack had been left to find it out for [himself]78-jack . Then , again , [she]79-dodo was engaged to [a man who was hopelessly and entirely in love with [her]79-dodo]2038-a man who was hopelessly and entirely in love with her , and for whom , apart from a quiet , unemotional liking , [she]79-dodo did not care two straws , except in so far as [he]2038-a man who was hopelessly and entirely in love with her was immensely rich and had a title , two golden keys which unlocked the most secret doors of [that well - furnished apartment known as Society , which constituted [Dodo]79-dodo 's world]2039-that well - furnished apartment known as society , which constituted dodo 's world . Hitherto [her]79-dodo position had been precarious : [she]79-dodo had felt that [she]79-dodo was on trial . [Her]79-dodo personality , [her]79-dodo great attractiveness and talents , had secured for [herself]79-dodo a certain footing on the very da√Øs of [that room]2040-that room ; but [she]79-dodo had always known that unless [she]79-dodo married brilliantly [she]79-dodo would not be sure of [her]79-dodo position . If [she]79-dodo married [a man who would not be always certain of commanding whatever money and position ‚Äî for [she]79-dodo would never have married [a wealthy brewer]2042-a wealthy brewer]2041-a man who would not be always certain of commanding whatever money and position ‚Äî for she would never have married a wealthy brewer ‚Äî could command , or , worst of all , if in [her]79-dodo unwillingness to accept anything but the best [she]79-dodo could get , [she]79-dodo did not marry at all , [Dodo]79-dodo knew that [she]79-dodo never would have that unquestioned position that [she]79-dodo felt was indispensable to [her]79-dodo . [Jack]78-jack knew all this perfectly well ‚Äî in fact [Dodo]79-dodo had referred to it that morning ‚Äî and [he]78-jack accepted it philosophically as being inevitable . But what [he]78-jack did not like was being told that [he]78-jack would not have done on general grounds , that [he]78-jack was too fond of [his]78-jack own way , that [he]78-jack would not have given [Dodo]79-dodo rein enough . [He]78-jack had known [Dodo]79-dodo too long and too well , when [he]78-jack proposed to [her]79-dodo , to have any of [a lover]2043-a lover 's traditional blindness to the faults of [his]78-jack love . [He]78-jack knew that [she]79-dodo was , above all things , strongly dramatic , that [she]79-dodo moved with a view to effect , that [she]79-dodo was unscrupulous in what [she]79-dodo did , that [her]79-dodo behaviour was sometimes in questionable taste ; but this [he]78-jack swallowed whole , so to speak . [He]78-jack was genuinely attached to [her]79-dodo , and felt that [she]79-dodo possessed the qualities that [he]78-jack would most like to have in [[his]78-jack wife]325-his wife . [Bertie]77-bertie had said to [him]78-jack that morning that [she]79-dodo was stimulating , and would not wear well . Stimulating [she]79-dodo certainly was ‚Äî what [lovable woman]2045-lovable woman is not?‚Äîand personally [he]78-jack had known [her]79-dodo long , and [she]79-dodo did wear well . The hidden depths and unsuspected shallows were exactly what [he]78-jack loved [her]79-dodo for ; [no one]2046-no one ever fell in love with [a canal]2047-a canal ; and though [the shallows]2048-the shallows were commoner than [the depths]2049-the depths , and [their]2048-the shallows presence was sometimes indicated by a rather harsh jarring of the keel , yet [he]78-jack believed , fully and sincerely , in the dark , mysterious depths for love to lose itself in . These reflections were the outcome of an intimate knowledge of [Dodo]79-dodo in the mind of [a man who was in the habit of being honest with [himself]2053-a man who was in the habit of being honest with himself and the object of his love and the object of [his]2053-a man who was in the habit of being honest with himself and the object of his love love]2053-a man who was in the habit of being honest with himself and the object of his love , a quality rare enough whether [the lover]2054-the lover is rejected or accepted . [He]78-jack had had time to think over the matter quietly to [himself]78-jack . [He]78-jack knew , and had known for many weeks , that [Dodo]79-dodo was out of [his]78-jack reach , and [he]78-jack sat down and thought about the inaccessible fruit , not with the keen feelings of [one who still hoped to get it]2055-one who still hoped to get it , but with a resignation which recognised that the fruit was desirable , but that it must be regarded from a purely speculative point of view . And to do [him]78-jack justice , though [he]78-jack was very sorry for [himself]78-jack , [he]78-jack was much more sorry for [Chesterford]80-chesterford . [Chesterford]80-chesterford was [[his]78-jack cousin]2056-his cousin , [they]2057-they had been brought up together at [Eton]8-eton and [Oxford]9-oxford , and [he]78-jack knew [him]80-chesterford with that intimacy which is the result of years alone . [[Chesterford]80-chesterford 's old friends]2058-chesterford 's old friends had all a great respect and liking for [him]80-chesterford . As [Dodo]79-dodo had said , "[0-i] [He]353-he was [an honest man]310-an honest man if [you]355-you like . " [Slight acquaintances]89-slight acquaintances called [him]80-chesterford slow and rather stupid , which was true on purely intellectual grounds . [He]80-chesterford was very loyal , and very much devoted to what [he]80-chesterford considered [his]80-chesterford duty , which consisted in being [an excellent landlord]2059-an excellent landlord and [J.P. of [[his]80-chesterford county]2061-his county]2060-j.p. of his county , in voting steadily for the Conservative party in [the House of Lords]2062-the house of lords , in giving largely and anonymously to [good objects]2063-good objects , in going to [Church]2064-church on Sunday morning , where [he]80-chesterford sang hymns with fervour , and read lessons with respect , in managing a hunt in a liberal and satisfactory manner , and in avoiding any introspection or speculation about problems of life and being . [He]80-chesterford walked through [the world]321-the world with an upright gait , without turning [his]80-chesterford eyes or [his]80-chesterford steps to the right hand or the left , without ever concerning [himself]80-chesterford with what was not [his]80-chesterford business , but directing all [his]80-chesterford undoubtedly sterling qualities to that . [He]80-chesterford had a perfect genius for doing [his]80-chesterford duty . [Nobody]247-nobody had ever called [him]80-chesterford shallow or foolish , but [nobody on the other hand]2067-nobody on the other hand had ever , called [him]80-chesterford either deep or clever . [He]80-chesterford had probably only made one real mistake in [his]80-chesterford life , and that was when [he]80-chesterford asked [Dodo]79-dodo to marry [him]80-chesterford ; and [we]2068-we have seen that [Jack]78-jack , who knew [Dodo]79-dodo well , and [whose opinion might be considered to be based on good grounds]2069-whose opinion might be considered to be based on good grounds , thought that [Dodo]79-dodo had committed [her]79-dodo first grand error in accepting [him]80-chesterford . The worst of the business certainly was that [he]80-chesterford was in love with [Dodo]79-dodo . If [he]80-chesterford had been [a different sort of man]2070-a different sort of man , if [he]80-chesterford had proposed to [Dodo]79-dodo with the same idea that [Dodo]79-dodo had , when [she]79-dodo accepted [him]80-chesterford , if [he]80-chesterford had wanted [a brilliant and fascinating woman to walk through life with , who could not fail to be popular]2071-a brilliant and fascinating woman to walk through life with , who could not fail to be popular , end who would do the duties of [a mistress of [a great house]2073-a great house]2072-a mistress of a great house in a regal fashion , [he]80-chesterford could not have chosen better . But what [he]80-chesterford wanted in [a wife]348-a wife was [someone to love]2075-someone to love . [He]80-chesterford loved [Dodo]79-dodo , and apparently it had not entered [his]80-chesterford calculations that [she]79-dodo , in accepting [him]80-chesterford , might be doing it from a different standpoint from [his]80-chesterford own in proposing to [her]79-dodo . [Dodo]79-dodo had smiled on [him]80-chesterford with the air of [a benignant goddess who marries [a mortal]2077-a mortal]2076-a benignant goddess who marries a mortal , when [he]80-chesterford offered [her]79-dodo [his]80-chesterford hand and heart , and [he]80-chesterford had taken that smile as a fulfilment of [his]80-chesterford own thought . [Decidedly Jack]78-jack might have justification for feeling apprehensive . [Jack]78-jack 's only hope lay in that vein which did exist in [Dodo]79-dodo , and which [she]79-dodo had manifested in that outburst of tears the night before . [He]80-chesterford put it down to [her]79-dodo dramatic instincts to a large extent , but [he]80-chesterford knew there was something besides , for [Dodo]79-dodo did not care to play to [an empty house]2078-an empty house , and the presence of [[her]79-dodo future husband]2079-her future husband alone constituted anything but a satisfactory audience . [Jack]78-jack had always had a considerable belief in [Dodo]79-dodo : [her]79-dodo attractiveness and cleverness were , of course , beyond dispute , and required proof no more than the fact that the sun rose in the morning ; but [he]80-chesterford believed in something deeper than this , which prompted such actions as these . [He]80-chesterford felt that there was some emotion that [she]79-dodo experienced at that moment , of which [her]79-dodo tears were the legitimate outcome , and , as [he]80-chesterford thought of this , there occurred to [him]80-chesterford the remark that [Dodo]79-dodo had made that morning , when [she]79-dodo expressed [her]79-dodo regret at never having felt the sort of love that [she]79-dodo knew [Chesterford]80-chesterford felt for [her]79-dodo . [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane was perhaps perfectly happy that night . Was not [[her]90-mrs. vane daughter]2080-her daughter engaged to [a marquis]2081-a marquis and [a millionaire]2082-a millionaire ? Was not [[her]90-mrs. vane house]2083-her house going to be filled with the brightest and best of [[our]2084-our land]2085-our land ? [She]90-mrs. vane had often felt rather resentful against [Dodo]79-dodo , who alternately liked and despised people whom [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane would have given [her]90-mrs. vane right hand to be in a position to like , and both hands to be in a position to despise . [Mr. Vane]91-mr. vane was kept still more in the background . [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane said [she]90-mrs. vane was quite royal , which , of course , explains it . " "[90-mrs. vane] [I]0-i ca n't conceive what [you]78-jack 're talking about , " remarked [Dodo]79-dodo . "[0-i] It seems to [me]0-i to be sheer nonsense . " [Jack]78-jack smiled . "[0-i] On the whole , [I]0-i think it is sheer nonsense , " [he]0-i said . "[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i 'll come . " [Dodo]79-dodo swept [him]0-i the prettiest little curtsey . "[0-i] How good of [you]78-jack , " [she]79-dodo said . "[0-i] Good - night , [Jack]78-jack . " "[393-a nice gentleman] No , [I]0-i expect it is n't worth while , " said [Jack]78-jack . There is a particular beauty about [the Thames valley]2127-the thames valley for which [you]78-jack may search for years elsewhere , and not find ; a splendid lavishness in the way that [the woods]2128-the woods are cast down broadcast along [the river]2129-the river , and a princely extravagance of thick lush hayfields , that seem determined not to leave a spare inch of land between them and [the water]2130-the water . The whole scene has been constructed with a noble disregard of expense , in the way of water , [land]2131-land , and warm wood - land air . The tall , clean - limbed beech - trees have room to stretch their great , lazy arms without being prosecuted for [their]2128-the woods clumsy trespasses , and the squirrels that chatter at [you]78-jack from [[their]2128-the woods green houses]2132-their green houses seem to have a quite unusual sleekness about [them]2128-the woods , and [their]2128-the woods insolent criticisms to each other about [your]78-jack walk , and general personal unattractiveness , are inspired by a larger share of animal spirits than those of other squirrels . As [you]78-jack row gently up in the middle of [the stream]2133-the stream , [you]78-jack may see a heron standing in [the shallows]2048-the shallows , too lazy to fish , too supremely confident to mind the approach of anything so inferior as [yourself]78-jack , and from the cool shadow of [the woods]2128-the woods [you]78-jack may hear [an old cock pheasant]2136-an old cock pheasant talking to [himself]2136-an old cock pheasant , and not troubling to practise a new and original method of rocketing in June , for [he]2136-an old cock pheasant knows that [his]2136-an old cock pheasant time is not yet . At this time of year , too , [you]78-jack need not trouble to look round , to see if there are large boats full of [noisy people]2137-noisy people bearing down on [you]78-jack ; like the pheasant , [their]2137-noisy people time is not yet . But now and then the long strings of creamy bubbles appearing on [the deep , quiet water]2138-the deep , quiet water , and a sound rich in associations of cool plunges into frothy streams , warns [you]78-jack that a lock is near . And above [you]78-jack may see [some small village clustering down to [the river]2129-the river 's edge]2139-some small village clustering down to the river 's edge , to drink of its sweet coolness , or a couple of shaggy - footed cart - horses , looking with mild wonder at this unexpected method of locomotion , lifting [their]2141-their dripping noses from the bright gravelly shallows to stare at [you]78-jack , before [they]2141-their proceed to finish [their]2141-their evening watering . [Dodo]79-dodo was very fond of [the Thames valley]2127-the thames valley , and [she]79-dodo really enjoyed giving up a day of June in [London]2-london to [the woods]2128-the woods and [waters]2144-waters . [They]2145-they were to start quite early in the morning , [Dodo]79-dodo explained , and [everyone]363-everyone was to wear [their]363-everyone very oldest clothes , for [they]363-everyone were going to play ducks and drakes , and drink milk in dairies , and pick buttercups , and get entirely covered with freckles . [Dodo]79-dodo [herself]79-dodo never freckled , and [she]79-dodo was conscious of looking rather better for a slight touch of the sun , and it would be very dear of [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian if [she]96-mrs. vivian would come too , if [she]96-mrs. vivian did n't mind being silly all day ; and , if so , would [she]96-mrs. vivian call for [them]2145-they , as [they]2145-they were on [her]96-mrs. vivian way ? [Chesterford]80-chesterford , of course , was going , and [Jack]78-jack , and [Maud]81-maud and [[her]81-maud mother]2147-her mother ; it was quite a small party ; and was n't [Jack]78-jack a dear ? [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane had got hold of a certain idea about [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian , distinctly founded on fact . [She]96-mrs. vivian was one of those women who can not help making an impression . How it is done , or exactly what it is , [one]2148-one would be puzzled to define , but [everyone]363-everyone noticed when [she]96-mrs. vivian came info [a room]2150-a room , and was aware when [she]96-mrs. vivian went out . It was not [her]96-mrs. vivian personal appearance , for [she]96-mrs. vivian was short rather than tall , stout rather than graceful , and certainly middle - aged rather than young . [Dodo]79-dodo has mentioned the effect [she]96-mrs. vivian produced on [her]96-mrs. vivian , and [many people]2151-many people felt in the same way that [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian was somehow on a higher plane than [they]2151-many people , that [her]96-mrs. vivian mind was cast in a larger mould . Happily for [our]2152-our peace of mind [such people]2153-such people are not very common ; [most of [[our]2152-our fellow - men]2155-our fellow - men]2154-most of our fellow - men are luckily much on the same level , and [they]2154-most of our fellow - men are not more than [units among units]2156-units among units . But [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian was much more than a unit . [Dodo]79-dodo had said of [her]96-mrs. vivian that [she]96-mrs. vivian was two or three at least . And evidently nothing was further from [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian 's wishes than trying to make an impression , in fact , the very impressive element was rather due to [her]96-mrs. vivian extreme naturalness . [We]2152-our are most of [us]2152-our so accustomed to see [people]308-people behave , and to behave [ourselves]2152-our , in a manner not quite natural , that to see anyone who never does so , is in itself calculated to make [one]2148-one rather nervous . [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian evidently intended to take [her]96-mrs. vivian life up again at the point where [she]96-mrs. vivian had left off , so to speak ‚Äî in other words , at the period before [her]96-mrs. vivian marriage . Of [[her]96-mrs. vivian husband]387-her husband , perhaps , the less said the better . [He]387-her husband died , owing to an accident , after ten years of married unhappiness , and left [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian poorer than [she]96-mrs. vivian had been before . After [his]387-her husband death [she]96-mrs. vivian had travelled abroad for two years , and then returned to [England]1-england to live with [[her]96-mrs. vivian sister]341-her sister , who had married [a rich judge]2161-a rich judge and kept [house]2162-house rather magnificently in [Prince 's Gate]11-prince 's gate . [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian accordingly settled down in [the "[0-i] extremely commodious " house in [Prince 's Gate]11-prince 's gate]2169-the " extremely commodious " house in prince 's gate , and , as [I]0-i said , took up [her]96-mrs. vivian life where it had left off . A standing grievance that [[her]96-mrs. vivian husband]387-her husband had had with [her]96-mrs. vivian was , that [she]96-mrs. vivian interested [herself]96-mrs. vivian in [the poor]2171-the poor , and in [the East End slums]2172-the east end slums , that [she]96-mrs. vivian went to [[cabmen]2173-cabmen 's shelters]2174-cabmen 's shelters , and espoused the cause of [overdriven factory girls]2175-overdriven factory girls . [He]387-her husband had told [her]96-mrs. vivian that it was meddling with [other people]2176-other people 's business ; that nothing was so objectionable as an assumption of charitable airs ; that [a woman who went to balls and dinner - parties]2177-a woman who went to balls and dinner - parties was a hypocrite if [she]2177-a woman who went to balls and dinner - parties pretended to care about the state of [the poor]2171-the poor , and that [she]2177-a woman who went to balls and dinner - parties only did it because [she]2177-a woman who went to balls and dinner - parties wished to appear unlike [other people]2176-other people . But [he]387-her husband altogether failed to perceive that [her]96-mrs. vivian actions were entirely uninfluenced by the impression they were to make , and mistook [her]96-mrs. vivian extreme naturalness for the subtlest affectation . " [Dodo]79-dodo meanwhile had walked [Chesterford]80-chesterford off among [the green cool woods]2204-the green cool woods that bordered [the river]2129-the river . [Dodo]79-dodo had an unlimited capacity for interfering in the course of destiny . " To [Dodo]79-dodo 's concrete mind this was somewhat discouraging , but [she]96-mrs. vivian determined to do [her]96-mrs. vivian best to reduce things to an equation in which the value of "[0-i] x " could be found in terms of some of those many symbols which [she]96-mrs. vivian did know . [Dodo]79-dodo had an inexhaustible fund of vivacity , which was a very useful instrument to [her]79-dodo ; like a watch - key that fits all watches , [she]96-mrs. vivian was able to apply it as required to very different pieces of mechanism . When [she]96-mrs. vivian wished to do honour to a melancholy occasion , for instance , [her]96-mrs. vivian vivacity turned any slight feeling of sorrow [she]96-mrs. vivian had into hysterical weeping ; when the occasion was joyful , it became a torrent of delightful nonsense . To - day the occasion was distinctly joyful . [She]96-mrs. vivian had a large sense of success . [Chesterford]80-chesterford was really [a very desirable lover]2209-a very desirable lover ; [his]80-chesterford immense wealth answered exactly the requirements of [Dodo]79-dodo 's wishes . " "[96-mrs. vivian] That 's what [she]96-mrs. vivian 's always doing , " said [Dodo]79-dodo . "[96-mrs. vivian] Waiting and watching with large serious eyes . " [Dodo]79-dodo was conscious again of the presence of [this unknown quantity]2214-this unknown quantity . " [Lord]2221-lord and [Lady Chesterford]100-lady chesterford were expected [home]282-home on the 6th of December . The marriage took place late in August , and [they]2223-they had gone off on [the yacht]2224-the yacht directly afterwards , in order to spend a few warm months in [the Mediterranean]15-the mediterranean . [Dodo]79-dodo had written [home]282-home occasionally to [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane , and now and then to [Jack]78-jack . To [Jack]78-jack [her]79-dodo letters had never been more than a word or two , simply saying that [they]2223-they were enjoying [themselves]2223-they enormously , and that [Jack]78-jack had been hopelessly wrong . [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane also had much reason to be satisfied . [She]90-mrs. vane had spent [her]90-mrs. vane autumn in [a variety of fashionable watering - places , where [her]90-mrs. vane dresses had always been the awe and wonder of [the town]2227-the town]2226-a variety of fashionable watering - places , where her dresses had always been the awe and wonder of the town ; [she]90-mrs. vane had met [many acquaintances , to whom [she]90-mrs. vane had poured out [her]90-mrs. vane rapture over [Dodo]79-dodo 's marriage]2228-many acquaintances , to whom she had poured out her rapture over dodo 's marriage ; had declared that [Chesterford]80-chesterford was most charming , and that [he]80-chesterford and [Dodo]79-dodo were quite [another [Adam]101-adam and [Eve]85-evelyn in [Paradise]16-paradise]2229-another adam and eve in paradise , and that [she]90-mrs. vane was really quite jealous of [Dodo]79-dodo . When [they]2230-they left [England]1-england , [they]2230-they had intended to spend the winter abroad and not come back till February , but early in December a telegram had arrived at [Winston]17-winston , [[Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford 's country house]2231-lord chesterford 's country house , saying that [they]2230-they would be back in ten days . About the same time [Jack]78-jack received a letter , saying that [their]2230-they change of plans was solely owing to the fact that [Dodo]79-dodo was rather tired of [the sea]2232-the sea , and the weather was bad , and that [she]79-dodo had never been so happy in [her]79-dodo life . [Dodo]79-dodo 's eagerness to assure [Jack]78-jack of this struck [him]78-jack as being in rather bad taste . [She]79-dodo ought to have entirely ignored [his]78-jack warnings . The happiness of [a newly - married woman]2233-a newly - married woman ought to be so absorbing , as to make [her]79-dodo be unaware of the existence of [other people]2176-other people ; and this consciousness in [Dodo]79-dodo of [her]79-dodo triumphant superiority of knowledge , led [him]78-jack to suppose [he]78-jack was right rather than wrong . [He]78-jack was unfeignedly sorry not to be sure that [she]79-dodo had been right . When [he]78-jack told [Dodo]79-dodo that [he]78-jack wished to be jealous of [Chesterford]80-chesterford , [he]78-jack was quite sincere . Since [he]78-jack could not have [Dodo]79-dodo [himself]78-jack , at any rate let [her]79-dodo make [someone]2235-someone happy . [Dodo]79-dodo also informed [him]78-jack that [they]2236-they were going to have a house - party that Christmas and that [he]78-jack must come , and [she]79-dodo had asked [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian , to show that [she]79-dodo was n't afraid of [her]79-dodo any longer , and that [Maud]81-maud was coming , and [she]79-dodo wished [Jack]78-jack would marry [her]79-dodo . Then followed a dozen other names belonging to [Dodo]79-dodo 's private and particular set , who had all been rather disgusted at [her]79-dodo marrying what [they]2236-they chose to call [a Philistine]2237-a philistine . It had been quite hoped that [she]79-dodo would marry [Jack]78-jack . [Jack]78-jack was not [a Philistine]2237-a philistine at all , though the fact of [his]78-jack having proposed to [her]79-dodo remained a secret . [Maud]81-maud , on the other hand , was [a Philistine]2237-a philistine ; and it was one of [Dodo]79-dodo 's merits that [she]79-dodo did not drop those who originally had claims on [her]79-dodo , when [she]79-dodo became [the fashion]2240-the fashion . [She]79-dodo was constantly trying to bring [Maud]81-maud into notice , but [Maud]81-maud resisted the most well - meant shoves . [She]81-maud had none of [Dodo]79-dodo 's vivacity and talents ; in fact , [her]81-maud talents lay chiefly in the direction of arranging the places at a dinner - party , and in doing a great deal of unnecessary worsted work . What happened to [her]81-maud worsted work [nobody]247-nobody ever knew . It was chiefly remarkable for the predominance of its irregularities , and a suggestion of damaged goods about it , in consequence of much handling . To [Dodo]79-dodo it seemed an incredible stupidity that [anyone]343-anyone should do worsted work , or , if [they]343-anyone did do it , not do it well . [She]79-dodo used to tell [Maud]81-maud that it was done much more cheaply in [shops]2243-shops , and much better . Then [Maud]81-maud would drop it for a time , and take to playing the piano , but that was even more oppressively stupid to [Dodo]79-dodo 's mind than the worsted work . [Maud]81-maud had a perfect genius for not letting [her]81-maud right hand know what [her]81-maud left hand was doing , a principle which was abhorrent to [Dodo]79-dodo in every application . The consequence of all this was , that [Dodo]79-dodo was apt to regard [[her]79-dodo sister]341-her sister as a failure , though [she]79-dodo still , as in the present instance , liked giving [Maud]81-maud what [she]79-dodo considered a helping hand . It must be confessed that [Dodo]79-dodo 's efforts were not altogether unselfish . [She]79-dodo liked [her]79-dodo environment to be as great a success as [herself]79-dodo , as it thus added to [her]79-dodo own completeness , just as a picture looks better in a good frame than in a shabby one . [Maud]81-maud , however , had no desire to be a success . [She]81-maud was perfectly happy to sit in the background and do the worsted work . [She]81-maud longed to be let alone . At times [she]81-maud would make [her]81-maud escape to [the iron works]2245-the iron works and try to cultivate the domestic virtues in attending to [[her]81-maud father]2246-her father . " This communication had only the effect of making [Jack]78-jack rather uncomfortable . Knowing what [he]78-jack did , [he]78-jack knew that this was not all genuine on [Dodo]79-dodo 's part . It was obviously an effort to keep it up , to use a vulgar term . And since it was not all genuine , the doubt occurred as to whether any of it was . [Jack]78-jack had a profound belief in [Dodo]79-dodo 's dramatic talents . That the need for keeping it up had appeared already was an alarming symptom , but the real tragedy would begin on that day when [Dodo]79-dodo first failed to do so . And from that moment [Jack]78-jack regarded [his]78-jack prophecy as certain to be fulfilled . The overture had begun , and in course of time the curtain would rise on a grim performance . [They]459-we drove up to the door , and entered [the large oak - panelled hall]2259-the large oak - panelled hall , hung all round with portraits of [the family]2092-the family . The night was cold , and there was a fire sparkling in the wide , open grate . This produced heartburnings of the keenest order in the mind of a small fox - terrier pup , who consisted mainly of head and legs , which latter [he]2261-an old collie , who was enjoying the fruits of a well - spent life on the hearthrug evidently considered at present more as a preventive towards walking than an aid . It was characteristic of [Chesterford]80-chesterford that all animals liked [him]80-chesterford . [He]80-chesterford had a tender regard for the feelings of anything that was dependent on [him]80-chesterford . [Dodo]79-dodo thought this almost inexplicable . [She]79-dodo disliked to see animals in pain , because [they]2263-they usually howled , but the dumb anguish of [a dog who considers [himself]2264-a dog who considers himself neglected neglected]2264-a dog who considers himself neglected conveyed nothing to [her]79-dodo . [Chesterford]80-chesterford was so completely happy , so terribly unconscious of what [Jack]78-jack felt sure was going on . " [Jack]78-jack found [himself]78-jack making a quantity of reflections , when [he]78-jack retired to [[his]78-jack room]2284-his room that night . [He]78-jack became aware that [he]78-jack had enjoyed [himself]78-jack more that evening than [he]78-jack had done for a very long time . [He]78-jack questioned [himself]78-jack as to when [he]78-jack had enjoyed [himself]78-jack so much , and [he]78-jack was distinctly perturbed to find that the answer was , when [he]78-jack had last spent an evening with [Dodo]79-dodo . [He]78-jack had formed an excellent habit of being exactly honest with [himself]78-jack , and [he]78-jack concluded that [Dodo]79-dodo 's presence had been the cause of it . It was a very unpleasant blow to [him]78-jack . [He]78-jack had accepted [her]79-dodo refusal with an honest determination to get over it . [He]78-jack had not moped , nor pined , nor striven , nor cried . [He]78-jack had no intentions of dying of a broken heart , but the stubborn fact remained that [Dodo]79-dodo exercised an unpleasantly strong influence over [him]78-jack . [He]78-jack could have repeated without effort all [she]79-dodo had said that night . [She]79-dodo had not said anything particularly remarkable , but somehow [he]78-jack felt that the most striking utterances of [other men]2285-other men and [women]408-women would not have produced any such effect on [him]78-jack . It really was very inconvenient . [Dodo]79-dodo had married [a man who adored [her]79-dodo , for whom [she]79-dodo did not care [two pins]2288-two pins ' heads , and [this man]372-this man was one of [[his]78-jack oldest friends]2290-his oldest friends]2287-a man who adored her , for whom she did not care two pins ' heads , and this man was one of his oldest friends . Decidedly there was something left - handed about this particular disposition of destiny . And the worst of it was that [Chesterford]80-chesterford was being hopelessly duped . About that [he]78-jack felt no doubt . [Dodo]79-dodo 's acting was so remarkably life - like , that [he]78-jack mistook it at present for reality . But the play must end some time , and the sequel was too dark and involved to be lightly followed out . [He]78-jack could not conceive why this elaborate drama on [Dodo]79-dodo 's part did not disgust [him]78-jack more . [He]78-jack wished [he]78-jack had been deceived by it [himself]78-jack , but having been behind the scenes , [he]78-jack had seen [Dodo]79-dodo , as it were , in [the green - room]2291-the green - room , putting on the rouge and powder . But failing that , [he]78-jack wished that a wholesome impulse of disgust and contempt had superseded [his]78-jack previous feelings with regard to [her]79-dodo . But [he]78-jack believed with [her]79-dodo that under the circumstances it was the best thing to do . The marriage was a grand mistake , true , but given that , was not this simply so many weeks of unhappiness saved ? Then [he]78-jack had an immense pity for [Dodo]79-dodo 's original mistake . [She]79-dodo had told [him]78-jack once that [she]79-dodo was no more responsible for [her]79-dodo philosophy than for the fact that [she]79-dodo happened to be five foot eight in height , and had black eyes and black hair . "[0-i] It was [Nature]108-nature 's doing , " [she]79-dodo had said ; "[0-i] go and quarrel with [her]108-nature , but do n't blame [me]0-i . If [I]0-i had made [myself]0-i , [I]0-i should have given [myself]0-i a high ideal ; [I]0-i should have had something to live up to . Now , [I]0-i have no ideal . The whole system of things seems to [me]0-i such an immense puzzle , that [I]0-i have given up trying to find a solution . [I]0-i know what [I]0-i like , and what [I]0-i dislike . Can [you]500-you blame [me]0-i for choosing the one , and avoiding the other ? [I]0-i like wealth and success , and society and admiration . In a degree [I]0-i have secured them , and the more [I]0-i secure [them]501-them the more reason [I]0-i have to be satisfied . To do otherwise would be like putting on boots that were too large for [me]0-i ‚Äî they are excellent for [other people]2176-other people , but not for [me]0-i . [I]0-i can not accept ideals that [I]0-i do n't feel . [I]0-i can understand [them]501-them , and [I]0-i can sympathise with [them]501-them , and [I]0-i can and do wish [they]501-them were [mine]0-i ; but , as [Nature]108-nature has denied [me]0-i them , [I]0-i must make the best of what [I]0-i have . " [Jack]78-jack felt hopeless against this kind of reasoning , and angry with [himself]78-jack for letting [this woman]2203-this woman have such dominion over [him]78-jack . In a measure [he]78-jack felt [himself]78-jack capable of views bounded by a horizon not so selfishly fatalistic , and the idea of the smoking chimney in [the cottage]2293-the cottage did not seem to matter , provided that [Dodo]79-dodo was sitting on the other side of the hearthrug . [He]78-jack would willingly have sacrificed anything else , to allow [himself]78-jack to give full reins to [his]78-jack thought on this point . But the grand barrier which stood between [him]78-jack and [Dodo]79-dodo , was not so much [her]2203-this woman refusal of [him]78-jack , but the existence of [[her]2203-this woman husband]387-her husband . At this [Jack]78-jack pulled [himself]78-jack up sharp . There are certain feelings of loyalty that still rank above all other emotions . [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham would certainly have classed such among the litany things . There was nothing heroic about it . It simply consisted in a sturdy refusal to transgress , even in vaguest thought , a code which deals with the most ordinary and commonplace virtues and vices . There is nothing heroic in [a street boy]2295-a street boy passing by [the baker]2296-the baker 's cart without a grab at the loaves , and it sounds almost puritanical to forbid [him]2295-a street boy to cast a glance at them , or inhale a sniff of [their]2297-their warm fragrance . "[0-i] Certainly this side of morality is remarkably dull , " thought [Jack]78-jack ; and the worst of it is , that it is not only dull but difficult . With practice [most of [us]2299-us]2298-most of us could become [a Simeon Stylites]2300-a simeon stylites , provided [we]2299-us are gifted with a steady head , and a constitution that defies showers . It is these commonplace acts of loyalty , the ordinary and rational demands of friendship and society , that are so dreadfully taxing to [most of [us]2299-us who have the misfortune not to be born [saints]2302-saints]2301-most of us who have the misfortune not to be born saints . Then [Jack]78-jack began to feel ill - used . "[0-i] Why [the deuce]503-the deuce should [Chesterford]80-chesterford be born [a marquis]2081-a marquis and not [I]0-i ? What has [he]80-chesterford done to have a title and fortune and [Dodo]79-dodo that [I]0-i have been given the chance to do ? " It struck [him]78-jack that [his]78-jack reflections were deplorably commonplace , and that [his]78-jack position ought to be made much more of . [He]78-jack wondered whether this sort of situation was always so flat . In novels there is always a touch of the heroic in [the faithful friend who is loyal to [[his]78-jack cousin]2056-his cousin , and steadily avoids [[his]78-jack cousin 's wife]2305-his cousin 's wife]2303-the faithful friend who is loyal to his cousin , and steadily avoids his cousin 's wife ; but here [he]78-jack is in identically the same situation , feeling not at all heroic , but only discontented and quarrelsome with this ill - managed world . Decidedly [he]78-jack would go to bed . Owing to a certain habit that [he]78-jack had formed early in life [he]78-jack slept soundly , and morning found [him]78-jack not only alive , but remarkably well and hearty , and with a certain eagerness to follow up what [he]78-jack had thought out on the previous night . [He]78-jack was in [an excellently managed household , which imposed no rules on [[its]2306-an excellently managed household , which imposed no rules on its inhabitants except that they should do what they felt most inclined to do inhabitants]2307-its inhabitants except that [they]2307-its inhabitants should do what [they]2307-its inhabitants felt most inclined to do]2306-an excellently managed household , which imposed no rules on its inhabitants except that they should do what they felt most inclined to do ; [he]78-jack was in congenial company , and [his]78-jack digestion was good . It is distressing how important those material matters are to [us]2308-we . The deeper emotions do but form a kind of background to [our]2308-we coarser needs . [We]2308-we come down in the morning feeling rather miserable , but [we]2308-we eat an excellent breakfast , and , in spite of [ourselves]2308-we , [we]2308-we are obliged to confess that [we]2308-we feel distinctly better . As [Jack]78-jack crossed [the hall]336-the hall , [he]78-jack met [a footman]2310-a footman carrying a breakfast tray into [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room . The door was half open , and there came from within the sounds of vigorous piano - playing , and now and then a bar or two of music sung in a rich , alto voice . These tokens seemed to indicate that [Miss Edith Staines]104-edith was taking [her]104-edith breakfast at the piano . [Jack]78-jack found [himself]78-jack smiling at the thought ; it was a great treat to find anyone so uniformly in character as [Miss Staines]104-edith evidently was . " "[78-jack] If [you]109-grantie mean the same as the case [I]0-i 'm thinking of , certainly not , " said [Jack]78-jack . "[0-i] Well , [I]0-i 'm sure this is very pleasant for [me]0-i , " said [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham , in high , cool tones . At this moment a shrill voice called [Dodo]79-dodo from [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room . "[0-i] [Dodo]79-dodo , [Dodo]79-dodo , " it cried , "[79-dodo] [the man]520-the man brought [me]0-i two tepid poached eggs ! Do send [me]0-i something else . Is there such a thing as a grilled bone ? " [Edith Staines]104-edith talked in a loud , determined voice , and emphasised [her]104-edith points with little dashes and nourishes of the dish of poached eggs . "[77-bertie] [Dodo]79-dodo , listen to this . " [She]104-edith ran [her]104-edith hands over the piano , and then broke out into a quick , rippling scherzo . The music flew on , as if all the winds of heaven were blowing it ; then it slowed down , halted a moment , and repeated itself till [Dodo]79-dodo burst out : "[79-dodo] Oh , [Edith]104-edith , it 's lovely ! [I]0-i want to dance . " [She]104-edith wheeled a table out of the way , kicked a chair across [the room]339-the room , and began turning and twisting with breathless rapidity . [Her]104-edith graceful figure looked admirable in the quick movements of [her]104-edith impromptu dance . [Bertie]77-bertie thought [he]77-bertie had never seen anything so deliciously fresh . [Dodo]79-dodo danced with peculiar abandon . Every inch of [her]104-edith moved in perfect time and harmony to the music . [She]104-edith had caught up a thin , Indian shawl from one of the sofas , and passed it behind [her]104-edith back , round [her]104-edith head , this way and that , bending , till at one moment it swept the ground in front of [her]104-edith , at another flew in beautiful curves high above [her]104-edith head , till at last the music stopped , and [she]104-edith threw [herself]104-edith down exhausted in an arm - chair . "[0-i] Oh , that was glorious , " [she]104-edith panted . "[0-i] [Edith]104-edith , [you]104-edith are [a genius]550-a genius . [I]0-i never felt like that before . [I]0-i did n't dance at all , it was the music that danced , and pulled [me]0-i along with it . " "[0-i] That was the best compliment [my]0-i music has ever received , " said [Edith]104-edith . "[0-i] That scherzo was meant to make [you]104-edith want to dance . Now , [Dodo]79-dodo , could [I]0-i have done that after eating two poached eggs ? [Handel]116-handel always reminds [me]0-i of high tea , particularly the muffins . [I]0-i 've often thought of taking the Salvation Army hymn - book and working the tunes up into fugual choruses , and publishing them as a lost work of Handel 's , [Noah]117-noah , or [[Zebedee]118-zebedee 's children]555-zebedee 's children , or [the Five Foolish Virgins]556-the five foolish virgins . " "[79-dodo] Yes ; but [your]79-dodo music is the expression of [your]79-dodo conclusions , is n't it ? " [Edith]104-edith sat down sternly , and buried [herself]104-edith in heir convictions . It was a perfect winter 's day , and when , two hours afterwards , [Dodo]79-dodo and [the others]2202-the others drove off to meet [the shooting - party]2324-the shooting - party , the grass in the shadow was still crisp with the light , hoar frost , but where the sun had touched [it]2325-it , [the fields]2326-the fields were covered with a moist radiance . It had just begun to melt the little pieces of ice that hung from the bare , pendulous twigs of the birch - trees , and send them , shivering to the ground . Through the brown bracken [you]2327-you could hear the startled scuttle of the rabbit , or the quick tapping of a pheasant , who had realised that schemes were on foot against [him]116-handel . A night of hard frost had turned the wheel - ruts into little waves and billows of frozen mud , which the carriage wheels levelled as [they]2324-the shooting - party passed over [them]2324-the shooting - party . [They]571-they caught up the shooting party shortly before lunch , and , as it was cold , [Edith]104-edith and [Dodo]79-dodo got out , leaving [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham [, who preferred being cold to walking under any circumstances]2328-, who preferred being cold to walking under any circumstances , to gather up the extra rugs round [her]105-miss grantham . "[116-handel] See that there 's a good fire , [Grantie]109-grantie , " called [Dodo]79-dodo after [her]105-miss grantham , "[109-grantie] and tell [them]571-they to have the champagne opened . " The sight of abundant game was too much for [Edith]104-edith , and , as [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford fell out of line to join [Dodo]79-dodo , [she]104-edith asked [him]80-chesterford if [she]104-edith might have a couple of shots . [The keeper]450-the keeper 's face expressed some reasonable surprise when [he]80-chesterford observed [Edith]104-edith snapping the cartridges into [her]104-edith gun with a practised hand . [His]80-chesterford previous views with regard to [women in connection with guns]2330-women in connection with guns were based upon the idea that [most women]2331-most women screamed , when [they]2331-most women saw a gun , and considered it a purely unaccountable weapon , which might go off without the least encouragement or warning , and devastate [the country]2090-the country for miles round . [He]80-chesterford was still more surprised when [he]80-chesterford saw [her]104-edith pick off a couple of pheasants with precision and deadliness of aim . [She]104-edith gave [her]104-edith gun back to [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford as [they]2333-they neared [the lodge]2334-the lodge , and volunteered to join [them]2333-they after lunch for an hour , if [they]2333-they did n't mind . [Chesterford]80-chesterford stole an appealing glance , at [Dodo]79-dodo , who , however , only gave [him]80-chesterford a half - amused , half - pitying look , and nodded assent . "[109-grantie] The worst of it is , " said [Edith]104-edith , "[109-grantie] [I]0-i care for such lots of things . There 's [my]0-i music , and then there 's any sort of game ‚Äî have [you]572-you ever seen [me]0-i play tennis?‚Äîand there is n't time for everything . [I]0-i am [a musician]573-a musician , and [a good shot]574-a good shot , and [an excellent rider]575-an excellent rider , and [a woman]323-a woman , and heaps of other things . [[Your]0-i worst enemies]577-your worst enemies do n't accuse [you]0-i of that . [I]0-i do n't mean to say that [I]0-i am , for that matter . [I]0-i only got eleven , and five of those were from [Chesterford]80-chesterford , and six from [myself]0-i . [You]0-i see , [Bertie]77-bertie did n't give [you]0-i any , if [you]0-i 're thinking of marrying [him]77-bertie . " "[77-bertie] Oh , [I]0-i 'm not going to marry [anybody]462-anybody , " said [Edith]104-edith . "[0-i] [You]0-i know [I]0-i get frightfully attached to [someone]2235-someone about three times a week , and after that never think of any of [them]2235-someone again . It is n't that [I]0-i get tired of [them]2235-someone , but [somebody else]584-somebody else turns up , and [I]0-i want to know [him]584-somebody else too . There are usually several good points about [everyone]363-everyone , and [they]2235-someone show those to [new acquaintances]586-new acquaintances first ; after that , [you]0-i find something in [them]2235-someone [you]0-i do n't like , so the best thing is to try [somebody else]584-somebody else . " "[584-somebody else] Oh , that depends on [the people]588-the people , " said [Dodo]79-dodo , meditatively . "[584-somebody else] [Some people]589-some people wear well , [you]0-i know , and those improve on acquaintance . Now [I]0-i do n't . The first time [a man]279-a man sees [me]0-i , [he]279-a man usually thinks [I]0-i 'm charming , and sympathetic , and lively . Well , so [I]0-i am , to do [myself]0-i justice . That remains all through . But it turns out that [I]0-i 've got a bad temper , that [I]0-i smoke and swear , and only amuse [myself]0-i . Then [they]2235-someone begin to think [they]2235-someone rated [me]0-i too high at first , and if [they]2235-someone happen to be [people who wear well]591-people who wear well [themselves]2235-someone , it is just then that [you]0-i begin to like [them]2235-someone , which is annoying . So [one]2148-one goes on , disgusting [the people]588-the people [one]2148-one wants to like , and pleasing [people whom [one]2148-one does n't like at all]595-people whom one does n't like at all . It 's fate , [I]0-i suppose . " [Dodo]79-dodo plucked a piece of dead bracken , and pulled it to bits with a somewhat serious air . "[597-you] [You]597-you ought n't to complain , [Dodo]79-dodo , " said [Edith]104-edith . "[597-you] [You]597-you 're married to [a man who , [I]0-i am sure , wears well , as [you]597-you call it , though it 's a dreadfully coarse expression , and [he]598-a man who , i am sure , wears well , as you call it , though it 's a dreadfully coarse expression , and he does n't seem to get tired of you does n't seem to get tired of [you]597-you]598-a man who , i am sure , wears well , as you call it , though it 's a dreadfully coarse expression , and he does n't seem to get tired of you . [I]0-i always wonder if it 's really worth while trotting [oneself]599-oneself out or analysing [one]2148-one 's nature in this way . [I]0-i do n't think it is . It makes [one]2148-one feel small and stupid . " "[2148-one] Ah , but it 's better to do it [yourself]597-you , than to feel that [other people]2176-other people think [you]597-you small and stupid , " said [Dodo]79-dodo . "[2176-other people] That 's disagreeable , if [you]597-you like . Wait till [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian comes , and [she]96-mrs. vivian 'll do it for [you]597-you . [She]96-mrs. vivian 's the only person who makes [me]0-i feel really cheap ‚Äî about three - halfpence a dozen , including the box . " "[96-mrs. vivian] Oh , but [she]96-mrs. vivian wo n't make [me]0-i feel small , " said [Edith]104-edith coolly , "[96-mrs. vivian] because [I]0-i 'm not small really . It 's only [myself]0-i that makes [me]0-i feel small . " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i should call [you]597-you morbidly modest , " said [Dodo]79-dodo . "[0-i] But here 's [[the keeper]450-the keeper 's cottage]509-the keeper 's cottage . [I]0-i 'm awfully hungry . [I]0-i hope [they]450-the keeper 've brought some p√¢t√© , Do n't [you]597-you like p√¢t√© ? Come on , [Chesterford]80-chesterford , [they]450-the keeper can count the dead things afterwards . [Grantie]109-grantie 's waiting . [Jack]78-jack , pick up that pheasant by [you]78-jack . Have [you]78-jack shot well ? Look at the sun through those fir - trees ‚Äî isn't it lovely ? What a blessing it is one did n't happen to be born [a fool]313-a fool ! " [Dodo]79-dodo was sitting alone late in the afternoon . [The shooting - party]2324-the shooting - party had come back , and dispersed to [[their]2324-the shooting - party rooms]2336-their rooms to wash and dress . "[104-edith] [You]104-edith all look remarkably dirty and funny , " [Dodo]79-dodo had said when [they]2324-the shooting - party came in , "[104-edith] and [you]104-edith had better have tea sent up to [you]104-edith . Does shooting bring on the inspiration , [Edith]104-edith ? Take a bath . " [Edith]104-edith had gone up to [[her]104-edith room]2115-her room , after insisting on having two of [Dodo]79-dodo 's bottles of eau - de - cologne in [her]104-edith hot bath . "[104-edith] There is nothing so refreshing , " [she]104-edith said , "[104-edith] and [you]104-edith come out feeling like [a goddess]610-a goddess . " Certainly [Edith]104-edith looked anything but [a goddess]610-a goddess just now . [Her]104-edith hat was pushed rakishly on to the side of [her]104-edith head , there was a suggestion of missing hair - pins about [her]104-edith hair ; [she]104-edith wafted with [her]104-edith about [the room]339-the room a fine odour of tobacco and gunpowder ; [she]104-edith had burned [her]104-edith dress with a fusee head that had fallen off ; [her]104-edith boots were large and unlaced , and curiously dirty , and [her]104-edith hands were black with smoke and oil , and had a sort of trimming in the way of small feathers and little patches of blood . Decidedly , if [she]104-edith came out feeling or looking like [a goddess]610-a goddess , [the prescription]2341-the prescription ought to want no more convincing testimonial . But [she]104-edith insisted [she]104-edith had never enjoyed [herself]104-edith so much , [she]104-edith talked , and screamed , and laughed as if nothing serious had occurred since breakfast . As [Dodo]79-dodo sat in [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room , opening a few letters and skipping all except the shortest paragraphs in the Times , [she]79-dodo heard the noise of wheels outside , and hurried into [the hall]336-the hall to meet [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian . Somehow [she]79-dodo looked forward to [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian 's coming with a good deal of pleasure and interest . [She]79-dodo was aware that another strain in [the house]2114-the house might be advisable . [Bertie]77-bertie and [Jack]78-jack , and [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham and [Edith]104-edith , were all somewhat on the same lines . Personally , [she]104-edith very much preferred those lines ; and it was chiefly for [[her]104-edith husband]387-her husband 's sake that [she]104-edith wanted [the new arrival]2346-the new arrival . [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford had done [his]80-chesterford duty nobly , but [Dodo]79-dodo 's observant eye saw how great an effort it was to [him]80-chesterford ; at lunch [he]80-chesterford had been silent , at tea even more so . [Dodo]79-dodo acknowledged that [Edith]104-edith had relieved [the party]2347-the party from any sense of the necessity of supporting conversation , but it was obvious to [her]79-dodo that [Chesterford]80-chesterford was hopelessly out of [his]80-chesterford element , and [she]79-dodo felt a keen desire to please [him]80-chesterford . [She]79-dodo had sat by [him]80-chesterford after lunch , as [they]2348-they smoked and talked , before resuming the shooting , and [Dodo]79-dodo had patted [his]80-chesterford hand and called [him]80-chesterford a "[610-a goddess] [dear old darling]611-dear old darling " when [nobody]247-nobody happened to be listening , but [she]79-dodo had a distinct sense of effort all day in attending to [him]80-chesterford , and enjoying the company of [the others]2202-the others as much as [she]79-dodo wished . There was certainly a want of balance in [the party]2347-the party , and [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian 's weight would tend to keep things even . [Dodo]79-dodo had even aroused [herself]79-dodo to a spasmodic interest in [the new curate]2352-the new curate , but [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford had exhibited such unmistakable surprise at this new departure , that [she]79-dodo at once fell back on the easier and simpler expedient of blowing smoke rings at [him]80-chesterford , and drinking out of the same glass by mistake . [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian was extremely gracious , and apparently very much pleased to see [Dodo]79-dodo . [She]96-mrs. vivian kissed [her]96-mrs. vivian on both cheeks , and shook both [her]96-mrs. vivian hands , and said what a pleasant drive [she]96-mrs. vivian had had with dear [Maud]81-maud , and [she]96-mrs. vivian hoped [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford was as well and happy as [Dodo]79-dodo appeared to be , and [they]2353-they both deserved to be . "[611-dear old darling] And [you]612-you must have a great talk with [me]0-i , [Dodo]79-dodo , " [she]96-mrs. vivian said , "[79-dodo] and tell [me]0-i all about [your]612-you honeymoon . " [Dodo]79-dodo was pleased and rather flattered . [Apparently Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian had left off thinking [she]96-mrs. vivian was very small . Anyhow , it was a good thing to have [her]96-mrs. vivian . [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford would be pleased to see [her]96-mrs. vivian , and [he]80-chesterford was building some charming almshouses for [old women]2250-old women , who appeared to [Dodo]79-dodo to be supremely uninteresting and very ugly . [Dodo]79-dodo had a deep - rooted dislike for ugly things , unless [they]2353-they amused [her]79-dodo very much . [She]79-dodo could not bear babies . [Babies]2355-babies had no profiles , which seemed to [her]79-dodo a very lamentable deficiency , and [they]2355-babies were not nearly so nice to play with as kittens , and [they]2355-babies always howled , unless [they]2355-babies were eating or sleeping . But [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian seemed to revel in ugly things . [She]96-mrs. vivian was always talking to [drunken cabmen]483-drunken cabmen , or [workhouse people]2357-workhouse people , or [dirty little boys who played in the gutter]2358-dirty little boys who played in the gutter . [Dodo]79-dodo 's cometic interest in [the East End]12-the east end had been entirely due to [her]96-mrs. vivian . [That lady]2220-that lady had a masterly and efficient way of managing , that won [Dodo]79-dodo 's immediate admiration , and had overcome for the moment [her]96-mrs. vivian distaste for the necessary ugliness . Anything masterly always found a sympathetic audience in [Dodo]79-dodo . Success was of such paramount importance in [her]79-dodo eyes , that even [a successful organiser of days in [the country]2090-the country for [match - girls]2186-match - girls]2360-a successful organiser of days in the country for match - girls was to be admired , and even copied , provided the other circumstances of success were not too expensive . [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian was a complete and immediate success on this occasion . [Dodo]79-dodo made a quantity of mental notes on the best way to behave , when [you]2363-you have the misfortune to become middle - aged and rather plain . [Everyone who already knew [her]96-mrs. vivian]2364-everyone who already knew her seemed to consider [her]96-mrs. vivian arrival as the last drop in [their]2364-everyone who already knew her cup of happiness . [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford , on entering [the room]339-the room , had said , "[79-dodo] [[My]0-i dear]436-my dear [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian , this is too delightful of [you]96-mrs. vivian . [Jack]78-jack also had , so to speak , flown into [her]79-dodo arms . [She]79-dodo decidedly wanted the receipt . " [She]79-dodo looked across to [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford , who was talking to [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham , and laughing politely at [her]79-dodo apostolic jokes . "[377-your mother] Oh , [Dodo]79-dodo , [you]96-mrs. vivian ought to be very happy ! " [Dodo]79-dodo felt that this was rather like the ten minutes before dinner . "[96-mrs. vivian] [I]0-i am so anxious to meet [her]104-edith . [She]104-edith has a wonderful gift for music , [I]0-i hear . " At this moment the sound of hurrying feet was heard in [the hall]336-the hall . [The drawing - room]338-the drawing - room door flew open and [Edith]104-edith entered . " "[79-dodo] Really , [Dodo]79-dodo , " said [Edith]104-edith , "[79-dodo] [you]79-dodo ought to cultivate the musical talents of [[your]79-dodo establishment]645-your establishment . Last winter [I]0-i was in [the Pyrenees]646-the pyrenees , and there was only [an old sexton]647-an old sexton , who was also [a charcoal burner]648-a charcoal burner , and [[my]0-i maid]649-my maid , and [Charlie]114-charlie and [[his]114-charlie valet]650-his valet and [[his]114-charlie wife]325-his wife , but [we]652-we had magnificent music , and a midnight service on New Year 's Eve . [Charlie]114-charlie took tenor , and [Sybil treble]121-sybil treble , and [I]0-i alto , and [the sexton bass]653-the sexton bass . [You]79-dodo have no idea of the trouble it was to get [the sexton]654-the sexton to learn [his]654-the sexton part . [I]0-i had to hunt [him]654-the sexton up in [those little brutal sheds]655-those little brutal sheds , and thrust the book into [his]654-the sexton hand , and forbid [him]654-the sexton to eat chestnuts , and force [him]654-the sexton to drink porter and Spanish liquorice . Come on ; let 's begin . " The practice went off satisfactorily , and [Edith]104-edith expressed [herself]104-edith as pleased . [She]104-edith and [Dodo]79-dodo then had a talk to arrange what [Dodo]79-dodo called the "[79-dodo] Play - bill . " [Dodo]79-dodo had arranged to read the lessons , and wished to make a small selection of prayers , but there [Edith]104-edith put [her]104-edith foot down . "[79-dodo] No , [Dodo]79-dodo , " [she]104-edith said , "[79-dodo] [you]79-dodo 're taking a wrong idea of it . [I]0-i do n't believe [you]79-dodo 're serious . Now [I]0-i am . [I]0-i want to do this Mass because [I]0-i believe [we]656-we can do it well , but [I]0-i have n't the least confidence in [your]79-dodo reading prayers well , or caring at all about them . [I]0-i am rather in doubt about the lessons , but [I]0-i suppose [we]656-we can have those . " It was distinctly news to [Dodo]79-dodo that [Edith]104-edith was serious . For [herself]104-edith [she]104-edith had only wished to have a nice little amusement for Sunday morning , which , in [Dodo]79-dodo 's experience , was rather a tiresome time if [you]2375-you stopped at [home]282-home , but on the whole preferable there than at [a country church]2377-a country church . But [Edith]104-edith was really in earnest whatever [she]104-edith did , whether it was shooting , or music , or playing lawn - tennis . Frivolity , was the one charge [she]104-edith could not brook for a moment . [Her]104-edith amusements might , indeed , be frivolous , but [she]104-edith did them with all [her]104-edith heart . So the service was arranged to consist of a lesson , a Mass , and another lesson . The choice of lessons was left to [Dodo]79-dodo . Accordingly , next morning [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford and [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian drove off with [Maud]81-maud to [eleven o'clock church]2378-eleven o'clock church , leaving [the others]2202-the others still at breakfast . After that meal was over [Dodo]79-dodo announced [she]79-dodo was going to get [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room ready . [I]0-i have got the sweetest little praying - table [upstairs]337-upstairs , and a skull . Do [you]660-you think [we]657-we 'd better have the skull , [Edith]104-edith ? [I]0-i think it makes one feel Sunday - like . [I]0-i shall put the praying - table in the window , and shall read the lessons from there . " "[0-i] [Dear Edith]124-edith , " said [Dodo]79-dodo demurely , "[124-edith] [I]0-i 'm perfectly serious . [I]0-i want it all to be just as nice as it can be . " "[660-you] [You]660-you want to make it dramatic , " said [Edith]124-edith decidedly . "[660-you] Now , [I]0-i mean to be religious . [You]660-you are rather too dramatic at times , [you]660-you know , and this is n't an occasion for it . [You]660-you can be dramatic afterwards , if [you]660-you like . [Herr Truffen]111-herr truffen is awfully religious . [I]0-i used to go with [him]111-herr truffen to Roman Catholic services , and once to confession . " "[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i should like to be [a nice little nun]662-a nice little nun , " said [Dodo]79-dodo ; "[0-i] those black and white dresses are awfully becoming , with a dear trotty rosary , [you]660-you know , on one side , and a twisty cord round one 's waist , and an alms - box . [I]0-i think it will be charming . " [Dodo]79-dodo completed [her]79-dodo arrangements in good time , and forebore to make any more frivolous allusions to the service . [She]79-dodo was sitting in [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room , regarding [her]79-dodo preparations with a satisfied air , when [Herr Truffen]111-herr truffen was announced . [Dodo]79-dodo greeted [him]111-herr truffen in [the hall]336-the hall as if it was the most natural thing in [the world]321-the world that [he]111-herr truffen should be called upon to accompany [Edith]124-edith 's Mass. "[0-i] [We]665-we 're going to have service directly , if [you]124-edith 're ready . "[126-mr. arbuthnot] [[My]0-i dear [Professor]127-professor]666-my dear professor , this is delightful , " [she]104-edith said . "[127-professor] It 's quite like old times , is n't it ? "[2279-a showman] It 's a perfectly beastly day , " [he]80-chesterford said cheerfully , advancing to the fireplace . Sounds of music still came from [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room . "[757-a dripping sop] It 's no use telling [Edith]104-edith to come to tea , " remarked [Dodo]79-dodo . "[104-edith] [She]104-edith said the other day that if [anyone]343-anyone ever proposed to [her]104-edith , whom [she]104-edith cared to marry , [she]104-edith will feel it only fair to tell [him]343-anyone that the utmost [she]104-edith can offer [him]343-anyone , is to play second fiddle to [her]104-edith music . " [Edith]104-edith 's music was strongly exciting , and in the pause that followed , [Dodo]79-dodo went to the door and opened it softly , and a great tangle of melody poured out and filled [the hall]336-the hall . [She]79-dodo was playing the last few pages of the overture to an opera that [she]79-dodo had nearly completed . The music was gathering itself up for the finale . Note after note was caught up , as it were , to join an army of triumphant melody overhead , which grew fuller and more complete every moment , and seemed to hover , waiting for some fulfilment . Ah , that was it . Suddenly from below crashed out a great kingly motif , strong with the strength of [a man who is pure and true , rising higher and higher , till it joined the triumph overhead , and moved away , strong to the end]2412-a man who is pure and true , rising higher and higher , till it joined the triumph overhead , and moved away , strong to the end . There was a dead silence ; [Dodo]79-dodo was standing by the door , with [her]79-dodo lips slightly parted , feeling that there was something in [this world]2207-this world better and bigger , perhaps , than [her]79-dodo own little hair - splittings and small emotions . With this in [her]79-dodo mind , [she]79-dodo looked across to where [Chesterford]80-chesterford was standing . The movement was purely instinctive , and [she]79-dodo could neither have accounted for it , nor was [she]79-dodo conscious of it , but in [her]79-dodo eyes there was the suggestion of unshed tears , and a look of questioning shame . Though a few bars of music can not change the nature of the weakest of [us]2414-us , and [Dodo]79-dodo was far from weak , [she]79-dodo was intensely impressionable , and that moment had for [her]79-dodo the germ of a possibility which might ‚Äî who could say it could not?‚Äîhave taken root in [her]79-dodo and borne fruit . The parable of the mustard seed is as - old and as true as time . But [Chesterford]80-chesterford was not musical ; [he]80-chesterford had taken a magazine from the table , and was reading about grouse disease . [Dodo]79-dodo was sitting in a remarkably easy - chair in [[her]79-dodo own particular room at [the house in [Eaton Square]25-eaton square]2416-the house in eaton square]2415-her own particular room at the house in eaton square . As might have been expected , [[her]79-dodo room]2115-her room was somewhat unlike [other rooms]2418-other rooms . [It]2115-her room had a pale orange - coloured paper , with a dado of rather more intense shade of the same colour , an orange - coloured carpet and orange - coloured curtains . [Dodo]79-dodo had no reason to be afraid of orange colour just yet . It was [a room well calculated to make complete idleness most easy]2419-a room well calculated to make complete idleness most easy . The tables were covered with a mass of albums , vases of flowers , and a quantity of entirely useless knick - knacks . The walls were hung with several rather clever sketches , French prints and caricatures of [[Dodo]79-dodo 's friends]438-dodo 's friends . A small bookcase displayed a quantity of flaring novels and a large tune hymn - book , and in a conspicuous corner was [Dodo]79-dodo 's praying - table , on which [the skull]2421-the skull regarded [its]2421-the skull surroundings with a mirthless and possibly contemptuous grin . The mantelpiece was entirely covered with photographs , all signed by [[their]2422-their prototypes]2423-their prototypes . These had found [[their]2422-their quarters]2424-their quarters gradually becoming too small for [them]2422-their , and had climbed half way up the two - sides of a Louis Quinze mirror , that formed a sort of overmantel . The photographs were an interesting study , and included [representatives from a very wide range of classes]2425-representatives from a very wide range of classes . [No one]2046-no one ever accused [Dodo]79-dodo of being exclusive . In the corner of [the room]339-the room were a heap of old cotillion toys , several hunting - whips , and a small black image of the Virgin , which [Dodo]79-dodo had picked up abroad . Above [her]79-dodo head a fox 's mask grinned defiantly at another fox 's brush opposite . On the writing table there was an inkstand made of the hoof of [Dodo]79-dodo 's favourite hunter , which had joined [the majority shortly after Christmas]2428-the majority shortly after christmas , and the "[79-dodo] [Dodo]79-dodo " symphony , which had just come out with great √©clat at [the Albert Hall]2429-the albert hall , leant against the wall . [Dodo]79-dodo 's hands were folded on [her]79-dodo lap , and [she]79-dodo was lazily regarding a photograph of [herself]79-dodo which stood oh the mantelpiece . Though the afternoon was of a warm day in the end of May , there was a small fire on the hearth which crackled pleasantly . [Dodo]79-dodo got up and looked at the photograph more closely . " [Dodo]79-dodo was conscious of quite a fresh tide of interest in [her]79-dodo life . [Her]79-dodo intellectual faculties , [she]79-dodo felt , had been neglected . [She]79-dodo could not conceive why , because [she]79-dodo had [a husband]2439-a husband and [baby]764-baby , [she]79-dodo should be supposed not to care for other interests as well . [Chesterford]80-chesterford was [an excellent husband]2441-an excellent husband , with a magnificent heart ; but [Dodo]79-dodo had told [herself]79-dodo so often that [he]80-chesterford was not very clever , that [she]79-dodo had ceased trying to take an intellectual pleasure in [his]80-chesterford society , and [the baby]283-the baby could not be called intellectual by [the fondest parent]2443-the fondest parent at present .
