[The footman]2318-the footman told [him]78-jack [she]79-dodo had gone hunting . "[79-dodo] Is [Lord Chesterford]1342-lord chesterford up yet ? " said [Jack]78-jack . [Dodo]79-dodo was called that morning at six , and [she]79-dodo felt in very good spirits . There was something exhilarating in the thought of a good gallop again . There had been frost for a week before , and hunting had been stopped , but [Dodo]79-dodo meant to make up all arrears . And , on the whole , [her]79-dodo interview with [Jack]78-jack had consoled [her]79-dodo , and it had given [her]79-dodo quite a new feeling of duty . [Dodo]79-dodo always liked new things , at any rate till the varnish had rubbed off , and [she]79-dodo quite realised that [Jack]78-jack was making a sacrifice to [the same forbidding goddess]2762-the same forbidding goddess . [Dodo]79-dodo was not conscious of the least embarrassment , and determined to do [her]79-dodo duty . It really was much better than yawning and being bored . [She]79-dodo had no idea how entertaining [she]79-dodo was to [herself]79-dodo . And [Chesterford]80-chesterford had lost [his]80-chesterford hang - dog look . [He]80-chesterford put [her]79-dodo hat straight for [her]79-dodo , and gave [her]79-dodo a little kiss just as [he]80-chesterford used to . After all , things were not so bad . It was a perfect morning . [They]2765-they left [the house]2114-the house about a quarter to seven , and [the world]321-the world was beginning to wake again . There was a slight hoar - frost on the blades of grass that lined [the road]257-the road , and on the sprigs of bare hawthorn . In the east the sky was red with the coming day . [Dodo]79-dodo sniffed the cool morning air with a sense of great satisfaction . "[290-old boy] Decidedly [somebody]511-somebody washes [the world]321-the world every night , " [she]79-dodo said , "[511-somebody] and those are the soapsuds which are still clinging to the grass . What nice clean soap , all in little white crystals and spikes . And oh , how good it smells ! Look at those poor little devils of birds looking for [their]511-somebody breakfast . [You]80-chesterford get five hours by lunch - time . " [None of [[Dodo]79-dodo 's worst enemies]2770-dodo 's worst enemies]2769-none of dodo 's worst enemies accused [her]79-dodo of riding badly . [She]79-dodo had a perfect seat , and that mysterious communication with [her]79-dodo horse that seems nothing short of magical . "[80-chesterford] If [you]80-chesterford tell [your]80-chesterford horse to do a thing the right way , " [she]79-dodo used to say , "[1363-he] [he]1363-he does it . It is inevitable . " [Dodo]79-dodo had a most enjoyable day 's hunting , and returned [home]282-home well pleased with [herself]79-dodo and [everybody else]419-everybody else . [They]2773-they went hunting every morning , and [Dodo]79-dodo began to form very high hopes of [[her]79-dodo new child]2774-her new child , as [she]79-dodo called [her]79-dodo ideal . The bad days did not seem to be the least imminent . [Chesterford]80-chesterford behaved almost like [a lover]2043-a lover again in the light of [Dodo]79-dodo 's new smiles . [He]80-chesterford kept [his]80-chesterford bad times to [himself]80-chesterford . [They]2776-they came in the evening usually when [the others]2202-the others had gone to bed . [He]80-chesterford used to sit up late by [himself]80-chesterford over [his]80-chesterford study fire , thinking hopelessly , of the day that had gone and the day that was to come . It was a constant struggle not to tell [Dodo]79-dodo all [he]80-chesterford knew . [He]80-chesterford could scarcely believe that [he]80-chesterford had heard what [Maud]81-maud had said , or that [he]80-chesterford ever had had that interview with [Jack]78-jack . [He]80-chesterford could not reconcile these things with [Dodo]79-dodo 's altered behaviour , and [he]80-chesterford gave it up . [Dodo]79-dodo was tired of [him]80-chesterford , and [he]80-chesterford knew that [he]80-chesterford loved [her]81-maud more than ever . A more delicately - strung mind might almost have given way under the hourly struggle , but it is the fate of [a healthy simple man]2778-a healthy simple man to be capable of more continued suffering than one more highly developed . The latter breaks down , or [he]80-chesterford gets numbed with the pain ; but [Chesterford]80-chesterford went on living under the slow ache , and [his]80-chesterford suffering grew no less . But through it all [he]80-chesterford looked back with deep gratitude to the chance that had sent [Dodo]79-dodo in [his]80-chesterford way . [He]80-chesterford did not grow bitter , and realised in the midst of [his]80-chesterford suffering how happy [he]80-chesterford had been . [He]80-chesterford had only one strong wish . "[99-god] Oh , [God]99-god , " [he]80-chesterford cried , "[99-god] give [me]0-i [her]1367-her back for one moment ! Let [her]1367-her be sorry just once for [my]0-i sake . " But there is a limit set to human misery , and the end had nearly come . It was about a fortnight after [Jack]78-jack had gone . [Maud]81-maud and [Mr. Spencer]154-mr. spencer had gone too , but [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian was with [them]2779-them still . [Dodo]79-dodo had more than once thought of telling [her]96-mrs. vivian what had happened , but [she]79-dodo could not manage it . When [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian had spoken of going , [Dodo]79-dodo entreated [her]79-dodo to stop , for [she]79-dodo had a great fear of being left alone with [Chesterford]80-chesterford . [They]2779-them had been out hunting , and [Dodo]79-dodo had got [home]282-home first . It was about three in the afternoon , and it had begun to snow . [She]79-dodo had had lunch , and was sitting in [the morning - room]2781-the morning - room in a drowsy frame of mind . [She]79-dodo was wondering whether [Chesterford]80-chesterford had returned , and whether [he]80-chesterford would come up and see [her]79-dodo , and whether [she]79-dodo was not too lazy to exert [herself]79-dodo . [She]79-dodo heard [a carriage]2782-a carriage come slowly up [the drive]2783-the drive , and did not feel interested enough to look out of the window . [She]79-dodo was sitting with [her]79-dodo shoes off warming [her]79-dodo feet at the fire , with a novel in [her]79-dodo lap , which [she]79-dodo was not reading , and a cigarette in [her]79-dodo hand . [She]79-dodo heard the opening and shutting of doors , and slow steps on the stairs . Then the door opened and [Mrs. Vivian]96-mrs. vivian came in . [Dodo]79-dodo had seen that look in [her]79-dodo face once before , when [she]79-dodo was riding in [the Park]244-the park with [Jack]78-jack , and a fearful certainty came upon [her]79-dodo . [You]1369-you will not be able to see [him]1368-he for half an hour . The operation is going on now . " [Dodo]79-dodo sat perfectly still . "[1376-them] Oh , [Chesterford]80-chesterford , " [she]79-dodo sobbed , "[1376-them] [I]0-i have wronged [you]80-chesterford cruelly , and [I]0-i can never make it up . [I]0-i will tell [you]80-chesterford all . " "[0-i] There is no need , " said [he]1373-any man ; "[0-i] [I]0-i knew it all along . " [Dodo]79-dodo raised [her]79-dodo head . Picture to [yourself]2797-yourself , or let [me]79-dodo try to picture for [you]2797-yourself , [a long , low , rambling house , covering [a quite unnecessary area of ground]2799-a quite unnecessary area of ground , with many gables , tall , red - brick chimneys , unexpected corners , and little bow windows looking out from [narrow turrets]2800-narrow turrets]2798-a long , low , rambling house , covering a quite unnecessary area of ground , with many gables , tall , red - brick chimneys , unexpected corners , and little bow windows looking out from narrow turrets - [a house that looks as if [it]2801-a house that looks as if it had grown , rather than been designed and built had grown , rather than been designed and built]2801-a house that looks as if it had grown , rather than been designed and built . [The next occupant]2803-the next occupant had been a man who knew how to make [himself]0-i comfortable , but did not care in the least what sort of appearance [his]0-i additions would wear to [the world]321-the world at large ; to [him]0-i [we]2805-we may assign that uncompromising straight wing which projects to the right of the little core of grey stone . Then came a series of attempts to screen the puritanical ugliness of [the offending block]2806-the offending block . [Some one]2807-some one ran up two little turrets at one end , and a clock tower in the middle ; one side of [it]2807-some one was made the main entrance of [the house]2114-the house , and two red - tiled lines of building were built at right angles to [it]2807-some one to form [a three - sided quadrangle]2809-a three - sided quadrangle , and [the carriage drive]2810-the carriage drive was brought up in a wide sweep to the door , and a sun - dial was planted down in the grass plot in the middle , in such a way that the sun could only peep at [it]2807-some one for an hour or two every day , owing to the line of building which sheltered [it]2807-some one on every side except the north . So [the old house]2811-the old house went on growing , and got more incongruous and more delightful with every addition . [The garden]2812-the garden has had to take care of itself under such circumstances , and if [the house]2114-the house has been pushing it back in one place , it has wormed itself in at another , and queer little lawns with flower beds of old - fashioned , sweet - smelling plants have crept in where [you]2814-you least expect them . [This particular garden]2815-this particular garden has always seemed to [me]79-dodo the ideal of what [a garden]2816-a garden should be . It is made to sit in , to smoke in , to think in , to do nothing in . [A wavy , irregular lawn]2817-a wavy , irregular lawn forbids the possibility of tennis , or any game that implies exertion or skill , and [it]2815-this particular garden is the home of sweet smells , bright colour , and chuckling birds . There are long borders of mignonette , wallflowers and hollyhocks , and many old - fashioned flowers , which are going the way of all old fashions . [London]2-london pride , with its delicate spirals and star - like blossoms , and the red drooping velvet of love - lies - a - bleeding . The thump of tennis balls , the flying horrors of ring - goal , even the clash of croquet is tabooed in [this sacred spot]2818-this sacred spot . Down below , indeed , beyond that thick privet hedge , [you]2814-you may find , if [you]2814-you wish , a smooth , well - kept piece of grass , where , even now ‚Äî if [we]2819-we may judge from white figures that cross [the little square]2820-the little square , where a swinging iron gate seems to remonstrate hastily and ill - temperedly with those who leave these reflective shades for the glare and publicity of tennis ‚Äî a game seems to be in progress . If [you]2814-you had exploring tendencies in [your]2814-you nature , and had happened to find [yourself]2814-you , on the afternoon of which [I]79-dodo propose to speak , in [this delightful garden]2821-this delightful garden , [you]2814-you would sooner or later have wandered into a low - lying grassy basin , shut in on three sides by banks of bushy rose - trees . The faint , delicate smell of their pale fragrance would have led [you]2814-you there , or , perhaps , the light trickling of a fountain , now nearly summer dry . Perhaps the exploring tendency would account for [your]2814-you discovery . [He]202-sir robert recounted at some length a series of tennis matches which [he]202-sir robert had taken part in a few years ago . A strained elbow had spoiled [his]202-sir robert chances of winning , but the games were most exciting , and it was generally agreed at the time that the form of [the players]2858-the players was quite first - class . " [Dodo]79-dodo had written to [Edith]104-edith from [Zermatt]51-zermatt , where [she]79-dodo was enjoying [herself]79-dodo amazingly . [Dodo]79-dodo was sitting in [the verandah of [the hotel]2885-the hotel]2887-the verandah of the hotel one afternoon , drinking black coffee and smoking cigarettes . Half [the hotel]2885-the hotel were scandalised at [her]79-dodo , and usually referred to [her]79-dodo as "[208-miss vane] [that Miss Vane]208-miss vane " ; [the other half]2890-the other half adored [her]79-dodo , and went [ on ] expeditions with [her]79-dodo , and took minor parts in [her]79-dodo theatricals , and generally played universal second fiddle . [Dodo]79-dodo enjoyed this sort of life . There was in [her]79-dodo an undeveloped germ of simplicity , that found pleasure in watching the slow - footed , cows driven [home]282-home from [the pastures]2892-the pastures , in sitting with [Jack]78-jack ‚Äî regardless of [her]79-dodo assumed name ‚Äî in [the crocus - studded meadows]2893-the crocus - studded meadows , or by the side of [the swirling glacier - fed stream]2894-the swirling glacier - fed stream that makes [the valley]2895-the valley melodious . [She]79-dodo argued , with great reason , that [she]79-dodo had already shocked all [the people that were going to be shocked]2896-the people that were going to be shocked , so much that it did n't matter what [she]79-dodo did ; while [the other contingent , who were not going to be shocked]2897-the other contingent , who were not going to be shocked , were not going to be shocked . " [Dodo]79-dodo had made great friends with [[the Prince]2616-the prince 's half - sister]2899-the prince 's half - sister , [a Russian on [[her]79-dodo mother]2147-her mother 's side]2900-a russian on her mother 's side , and [she]79-dodo was reading [her]79-dodo extracts out of [her]79-dodo unwritten book of the Philosophy of Life , an interesting work , which varied considerably according to [Dodo]79-dodo 's mood . "[0-i] [You]1481-you are [a Russian by nature and sympathy]1482-a russian by nature and sympathy , [[my]0-i dear]436-my dear [Princess]209-the princess , " [she]79-dodo was saying , "[1481-you] and [you]1481-you are therefore in a continual state of complete boredom . " [The Princess]2902-the princess stretched out a delicate arm . "[1481-you] [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i ever threw a stone in [my]0-i life , " [she]2902-the princess said dubiously . Anything , does to think about , and [nobody]247-nobody is bored unless [they]247-nobody think about being bored . When one has [the whole world]1487-the whole world to choose from , and only one subject in it that can make [one]2148-one feel bored , it really shows a want of resource to think about that . Then [you]1481-you ought to take walks and make [yourself]1481-you tired . " [The Princess]2902-the princess cast a vague eye on [the Matterhorn]35-the matterhorn . "[1481-you] That sort of horror ? " [she]2902-the princess asked . "[1481-you] No , [you]1481-you need n't begin with the Matterhorn , " said [Dodo]79-dodo , laughing . "[1481-you] Go to [the glaciers]1489-the glaciers , and get rather cold and wet . Boredom is chiefly physical . " "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm sure being cold and wet would bore [me]0-i frightfully , " [she]2902-the princess said . "[0-i] No , no ‚Äî a big no , " cried [Dodo]79-dodo . "[2046-no one] [No one]2046-no one is ever bored unless [they]2046-no one are comfortable . That 's the great principle . There is n't time for it . [You]1481-you can not be bored and something else at the same time . Being comfortable does n't count ; that 's [our]1491-our normal condition . But [you]1481-you need n't be uncomfortable in order to be bored . It 's very comfortable sitting here with [you]1481-you , and [I]0-i 'm not the least bored . [I]0-i should poison [myself]0-i if [I]0-i were bored : [I]0-i ca n't think why [you]1481-you do n't . " "[0-i] [I]0-i will do anything [you]1481-you recommend , " said [the Princess]2902-the princess placidly . "[0-i] [You]1481-you are [the only woman [I]0-i know who never appears to be bored . [I]0-i wonder if [[my]0-i husband]296-my husband would bore [you]1481-you]1492-the only woman i know who never appears to be bored . i wonder if my husband would bore you . [He]296-my husband is very big , and very good , and [he]296-my husband eats a large breakfast , and looks after [[his]296-my husband serfs]1494-his serfs . [He]296-my husband bores [me]0-i to extinction . [He]296-my husband would wear black for ten years if [I]0-i poisoned [myself]0-i . " A shade of something passed over [Dodo]79-dodo 's face . It might have been regret , or stifled remembrance , or a sudden twinge of pain , and it lasted an appreciable fraction of a second . "[0-i] [I]0-i can imagine being bored with [that kind of man]1495-that kind of man , " [she]1481-you said in a moment . [The Princess]2902-the princess was lying back in [her]2902-the princess chair , ' and did not notice a curious hardness in [Dodo]79-dodo 's voice . "[1495-that kind of man] [I]0-i should so - like to introduce [you]1481-you to [him]296-my husband , " said [she]1481-you . "[0-i] [I]0-i should like to shut [you]1481-you up with [him]296-my husband for a month at [[our]1496-our place on [the Volga]54-the volga]1497-our place on the volga . It snows a good deal there , and [he]296-my husband goes out in the snow and shoots animals , and comes back in the evening with a red face , and tells [me]0-i all about it . It is very entertaining , but a trifle monotonous . [He]296-my husband does not know English , nor German , nor French . [He]296-my husband laughs very loud . [He]296-my husband is quite safe . [I]0-i shall not be afraid . [He]296-my husband writes to [me]0-i every day , and suggests that [he]296-my husband should join [me]0-i here . " "[0-i] [I]0-i take all the pity [you]0-i have , " said [he]0-i , smiling gravely . "[0-i] [I]0-i want it more than any other poor devil [you]0-i might think of bestowing it on . [The Prince]2616-the prince thought that pity was quite a promising gift . [Dodo]79-dodo was a little uneasy after [he]0-i had gone . "[0-i] [I]0-i was in time the other day . " "[0-i] Let [us]1650-us do [her]1651-my sister justice , " said [the Prince]2616-the prince . "[1651-my sister] [She]1651-my sister was in time , but that was because [she]1651-my sister forgot what the time was . " "[1651-my sister] That 's the cause of [my]0-i being unpunctual , [dear]545-dear , " remarked [the Princess]2902-the princess . "[545-dear] To - day it was also because the thing like a horse would n't go , and [Dodo]79-dodo and [I]0-i talked a good deal . " [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane was eating [her]90-mrs. vane chicken with great satisfaction . A picnic with [a Prince]3000-a prince was so much capital to [her]90-mrs. vane . "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't think why [we]1650-us do n't all go and live in [the country]2090-the country always , " [she]90-mrs. vane said , "[1650-us] and have little picnics like this every day . Such a good idea of [[your]545-dear Highness]1181-your highness . So original ‚Äî and such a charming day . " [The Prince]2616-the prince remarked that picnics were not [his]2616-the prince invention , and that the credit for the weather was due elsewhere . "[1181-your highness] Oh , but [you]545-dear said last night [you]545-dear were sure it was going to be fine , " said [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane , floundering a little . "[545-dear] [Dodo]79-dodo , [dear]545-dear , did n't [you]79-dodo hear [the Prince]2616-the prince say so ? " "[2616-the prince] Here 's to the health of [[our]1650-us Zadkiel]1659-our zadkiel , " said [Dodo]79-dodo , "[1659-our zadkiel] may [his]1659-our zadkiel shadow , etc : Drink to [old Zadkiel]76-zadkiel , [Jack]78-jack , [the founder of the feast]1660-the founder of the feast , who stands [us]1650-us champagne . " "[1661-a poor devil whom you pity] Do [you]0-i find pity a satisfactory diet ? " asked [Dodo]79-dodo saucily . [She]79-dodo was determined not to be frightened of [him]2616-the prince any more . [The Prince]155-prince waldenech decided on a bold stroke . "[0-i] Pity is akin to love , " [he]155-prince waldenech said below [his]155-prince waldenech breath . But [he]155-prince waldenech had found [his]155-prince waldenech match , for the time being , at any rate . "[0-i] Do n't mistake it for it ['s cousin]1662-'s cousin , then , " laughed [Dodo]79-dodo . The conversation became more general . [The Princess]2902-the princess said [the mountains]3004-the mountains were too high and large , and [she]2902-the princess did n't like them . [Jack]78-jack remarked that it was purely a matter of degree , and [the Princess]2902-the princess explained that it was exactly what [she]2902-the princess meant , they were so much bigger than [she]2902-the princess was . [Mr. Spencer]154-mr. spencer plunged violently into the conversation , and said that [Mount Everest]59-mount everest was twice as high as [the Matterhorn]35-the matterhorn , and [you]3006-you never saw the top . [The Princess]2902-the princess said , "[1662-'s cousin] Oh , " and [Jack]78-jack asked how [they]3008-they knew how high it was , if the top was never seen , and [Mr. Spencer]154-mr. spencer explained vaguely that [they]3008-they did it with sextants . [Maud]81-maud said [she]81-maud thought [he]154-mr. spencer meant theodolites , and [Dodo]79-dodo asked a bad riddle about sextons . On the whole the picnic went off as well as could be expected , and [Dodo]79-dodo determined to have lunch out of doors every day for the rest of [her]79-dodo natural life . After lunch [Mr. Spencer]154-mr. spencer and [Maud]81-maud wandered away to pick flowers , presumably . [Mrs. Vane]90-mrs. vane moved [her]90-mrs. vane chair into the shade , in such a position that [she]90-mrs. vane could command a view of [the mountain]3009-the mountain , and fell asleep . [Jack]78-jack smoked a short black pipe , chiefly because [the Prince]2616-the prince offered [him]78-jack a cigar , and [Dodo]79-dodo smoked cigarettes and ate cherries backwards , beginning with the stalk , and induced [the Princess]2902-the princess to do the same , receiving two seconds ' start . "[1662-'s cousin] It 's a form of throwing stones , " [Dodo]79-dodo explained . [The "[1662-'s cousin] most distressin ' " old gentleman]3012-the " most distressin ' " old gentleman was sighted under a large white umbrella , moving slowly up [the path]3013-the path a little below [them]3014-them , and [Dodo]79-dodo insisted on inviting [him]1663-he to lunch , as it was certain that [he]1663-he had just left the table d'h√¥te . " [Edith]104-edith had stayed on with [the Granthams]212-the granthams till nearly the end of August . [She]104-edith declined to have breakfast with [the family]2092-the family , after [she]104-edith had been [there]267-there about a week , because [she]104-edith said it spoiled [her]104-edith mornings , and used to breakfast by [herself]104-edith at seven or half - past , which gave [her]104-edith extra ' two hours at [her]104-edith music ; and [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham complained of being wakened in the middle of the night by funeral marches . So [Edith]104-edith promised to play with the soft pedal down , which [she]104-edith never did . At lunch [Sir Robert]202-sir robert used to make a point of asking [her]104-edith how [she]104-edith had got on , and described to [her]104-edith [the admirable band in [the Casino at [Monte Carlo]60-monte carlo]3018-the casino at monte carlo]3017-the admirable band in the casino at monte carlo . [He]202-sir robert was always extremely genial to [her]104-edith , and , when [she]104-edith played to [them]3017-the admirable band in the casino at monte carlo in the evening , [he]202-sir robert would beat time with one hand . Now and then [he]202-sir robert even told [her]104-edith that [she]104-edith was not playing staccato enough , or that [he]202-sir robert heard it taken rather quicker at [Bayreuth]61-bayreuth . [Dodo]79-dodo had written to [Edith]104-edith saying that [she]104-edith was coming to stay with [her]104-edith in [September]62-september , and that [Edith]104-edith must be at [home]282-home by the second , because [she]104-edith would probably come that day or the third . [Edith]104-edith happened to mention this one night in the hearing of [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham , who had been firing off home - truths at [[her]191-lady grantham husband]387-her husband and [son]3021-son like a minute gun , in a low , scornful voice . This habit of [hers]104-edith was rather embarrassing at times . At dinner , for instance , that evening , when [he]197-bob had been airing [his]197-bob musical views to [Edith]104-edith as usual , [she]104-edith had suddenly said , ‚Äî "[1663-he] [You]1666-you do n't know how silly [you]1666-you 're making [yourself]1666-you , [Bob]197-bob . " "[0-i] [I]0-i should like to know [her]79-dodo , " said [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham . The remark was characteristic . [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham returned to the subject of [Dodo]79-dodo in the course of the evening . "[0-i] [Everyone]363-everyone says [she]79-dodo is so supremely successful , " [she]191-lady grantham said to [Edith]104-edith . "[79-dodo] What 's [her]79-dodo method ? " [All successful people]3028-all successful people , according to [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham , had a method . [They]3028-all successful people found out by experience what r√¥le suited [them]3028-all successful people best , and [they]3028-all successful people played it assiduously . To do [her]79-dodo justice , there was a good deal of truth in it with regard to [the people among whom [she]79-dodo moved]3029-the people among whom she moved . "[79-dodo] [Her]79-dodo method is purely to be dramatic , in the most unmistakable way , " said [Edith]104-edith , after some consideration . "[79-dodo] [She]79-dodo is almost always picturesque . To all appearance [her]79-dodo only method is to have no method . [She]79-dodo seems to say and do anything that comes into [her]79-dodo head , but all [she]79-dodo says and does is rather striking . [She]79-dodo can accommodate [herself]79-dodo to nearly any circumstances . [She]79-dodo is never colourless ; and [she]79-dodo is not quite like [anybody else [I]0-i ever met]1699-anybody else i ever met . [She]79-dodo has an immense amount of vitality , and [she]79-dodo is almost always doing something . It 's hopeless to try and describe [her]79-dodo ; [you]1700-you will see . [She]79-dodo is beautiful , unscrupulous , dramatic , warm - hearted , cold - blooded , and a hundred other things . " "[79-dodo] Oh , [you]0-i do n't do [her]79-dodo justice , [Edith]104-edith , " remarked [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham . "[104-edith] [She]79-dodo 's much more than all that . " [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham never said "[192-nora] good - night " or "[192-nora] good - morning " to [the members of [[her]191-lady grantham family]3031-her family]3030-the members of her family . [They]1702-they get on quite well enough without [my]0-i good wishes . It is very plebeian to be cheerful in the morning . " Although , as [I]192-nora have mentioned before , [Sir Robert]202-sir robert was an adept at choosing [his]202-sir robert conversation to suit [[his]202-sir robert audience]2855-his audience , there was one subject on which [he]202-sir robert considered that [he]202-sir robert might talk to [anyone]343-anyone , and in which [the whole world]1487-the whole world must necessarily take an intelligent and eager interest . [The Romans]214-the romans used to worship the bones and spirits of [[their]214-the romans ancestors]3035-their ancestors , and [Sir Robert]202-sir robert , perhaps because [he]202-sir robert was undoubtedly of [Roman imperial blood]3036-roman imperial blood , kept up the same custom . [Frank]204-frank used irreverently to call it "[192-nora] family prayers . " To know how [the Granthams]212-the granthams were connected with [the Campbells]215-the campbells , and [the Vere de Veres]216-the vere de veres , and [the Stanleys]217-the stanleys , and [the Montmorencies]218-the montmorencies , and [fifty other bluest strains]3037-fifty other bluest strains , seemed to [Sir Robert]202-sir robert to be an essential part of a liberal education . To try to be late for family prayers was hopeless . [They]3038-they were at no fixed hour , and were held as many times during the day as necessary . Sometimes they were cut down to a sentence or two ; suggested by the mention of some ducal name ; sometimes they involved a lengthy , pious orgie in front of [the portraits]3039-the portraits . To - night [Edith]104-edith was distinctly to blame , for [she]104-edith deliberately asked the name of [the artist who had painted the picture hanging over the door]3040-the artist who had painted the picture hanging over the door into [the library]3041-the library . [Sir Robert]202-sir robert , according to custom , seemed rather bored by the subject . "[192-nora] Let 's see , " [he]202-sir robert said ; "[192-nora] [I]0-i 've got no head for names . [Lord Linton]221-lord linton , that was [[my]0-i great - grand - father]1706-my great - grand - father ‚Äî [he]1706-my great - grand - father was made [an earl]1707-an earl after that portrait was taken ‚Äî saw a drawing in [a little shop in [Piccadilly]14-piccadilly]1708-a little shop in piccadilly , which took [his]221-lord linton fancy , and [he]221-lord linton inquired the name of [the artist]1709-the artist . " "[1717-a tall , handsome man] [A tall , handsome man]1717-a tall , handsome man , " remarked [Frank]204-frank to the fireplace . " "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm always saying to [Frank]204-frank , " said [Sir Robert]202-sir robert , "[0-i] that [you]204-frank have to judge [a man]279-a man by [himself]279-a man , and not by [[his]279-a man family]1728-his family . " [Sir Robert]202-sir robert was very gracious , and promised to send [her]104-edith a short memoir [he]202-sir robert was writing on the fortunes of [the family]2092-the family . It was to be bound in white vellum , with [their]2092-the family arms in gilt upon the outside . [Edith]104-edith , found [no one]2046-no one at [home]282-home but [a few servants on board wages]3046-a few servants on board wages , who did not seem at all pleased to see [her]104-edith . [She]104-edith devoted [her]104-edith evening to what [she]104-edith called tidying , which consisted in emptying the contents of a quantity of drawers on to the floor of [[her]104-edith room]2115-her room , and sitting down beside [them]2092-the family . [She]104-edith turned them over with much energy for about half an hour , and then decided that [she]104-edith could throw nothing away , and told [[her]104-edith maid]2947-her maid to put them back again , and played [her]104-edith piano till bed - time . [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham and [Nora]192-nora followed in a few days , and [Dodo]79-dodo was to come the same evening . [They]2092-the family were sitting put in [the garden]2812-the garden after dinner , when the sound of wheels was heard , and [Edith]104-edith went round to the front door to welcome [her]79-dodo . [Dodo]79-dodo had not dined , so [she]79-dodo went and "[0-i] made hay among the broken meats , " as [she]79-dodo expressed it . [Travelling]223-travelling produced no kind of fatigue in [her]79-dodo ; and the noise , and shaking , and smuts , that prey on most of [us]3050-us in [railway carriages]3051-railway carriages always seemed to leave [her]79-dodo untouched . [Dodo]79-dodo was particularly glad to get to [England]1-england . [She]79-dodo had had rather a trying time of it towards the end , for [Jack]78-jack and [the Prince]2616-the prince got on extremely badly together , and , as [they]3053-they both wished to be with [Dodo]79-dodo , collisions were frequent . [She]79-dodo gave the story of [her]79-dodo adventure to [Edith]104-edith with singular frankness as [she]104-edith ate [her]104-edith broken meats . "[0-i] [You]1749-you see , [Jack]78-jack got it into [his]78-jack head that [the Prince]2616-the prince is [a cad]1084-a cad and [a brute]1752-a brute , " said [Dodo]79-dodo . "[78-jack] [I]0-i quite admit that [he]78-jack may be , only neither [Jack]78-jack nor [I]0-i have the slightest opportunity for judging . Socially [he]78-jack is neither , and what [he]78-jack is morally does n't concern [me]0-i . How should it ? It is n't [my]0-i business to inquire into [his]78-jack moral character . [I]0-i 'm not [[his]78-jack mother]2877-his mother nor [[his]78-jack mother]2877-his mother [confessor]1755-confessor . [He]78-jack is [good company]1756-good company . [She]2983-his sister and [the Prince]2616-the prince are going to stay with [us]1760-us when [we]1760-us get back to [Winston]17-winston ; and [he]78-jack knows how to behave . [Jack]78-jack has a vague sort of feeling that [his]78-jack morals ought to prevent [him]78-jack from tolerating [the Prince]2616-the prince , which made [him]78-jack try to find opportunities for disliking [him]78-jack . But [Jack]78-jack did n't interfere with [me]0-i . " "[78-jack] No , " said [Edith]104-edith ; "[78-jack] [I]0-i really do n't see why [private individuals]1762-private individuals should n't associate with whom [they]1762-private individuals like . " "[0-i] That 's exactly [my]0-i view , " said [Dodo]79-dodo ; "[0-i] morals do n't come into the question at all . [I]0-i particularly dislike some of the cardinal virtues ‚Äî and the only reason for associating with [anybody]462-anybody is that [one]2148-one takes pleasure in [their]462-anybody company . Of course one would n't go about with [a murderer]1769-a murderer , however amusing , because [his]1769-a murderer moral deficiencies - might produce unpleasant physical consequences to [yourself]1770-you . But [my]0-i morals are able to look after [themselves]1762-private individuals . [I]0-i 'm not afraid of moral cut - throats . Morals do n't come into the social circle . [You]1770-you might as well dislike [a man]279-a man because [he]279-a man 's got a sharp elbow - joint . [He]279-a man wo n't use it on [your]1770-you ribs , [you]1770-you know , in [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room . To get under the influence of [an immoral man]1773-an immoral man would be different . [We]1774-we 'll , [I]0-i 've finished . Where are [the others]2202-the others ? " [Dodo]79-dodo and [Edith]104-edith strolled out , and [Dodo]79-dodo was introduced to [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham . " "[78-jack] Then [you]104-edith think it does n't matter whether society is composed of [people without morals]1784-people without morals ? " said [Edith]104-edith . "[104-edith] [I]0-i think it 's a bad thing that morals should deteriorate in any society , " said [Dodo]79-dodo ; "[0-i] but [I]0-i do n't think that society should take cognisance of the moral code . Public opinion do n't touch that . If [a man]279-a man is [a brute]1752-a brute , [he]279-a man wo n't be any better for knowing that [other people]2176-other people disapprove of [him]279-a man . If [he]279-a man knows that , and is worth anything at all , it will simply have the opposite effect on [him]279-a man . [He]279-a man very likely will try to hide it ; but that does n't make it any better . [A whited sepulchre]1788-a whited sepulchre is no better than a sepulchre unwhitened . [You]1789-you must act by [your]1789-you own lights . If an action does n't seem to [you]1789-you wrong nothing in [the world]321-the world will prevent [your]1789-you doing it , if [your]1789-you desire is sufficiently strong . [You]1789-you can not elevate tone by punishing offences . There are [no fewer criminals]1791-no fewer criminals since the tread - mill was invented and [Botany Bay]224-botany bay discovered . " "[0-i] [You]0-i mean that there would be no increase in crime if the law did not punish ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i mean that punishment is not the best way of checking crime , though that is really altogether a different question . [You]1789-you wo n't check immorality by dealing with it as a social crime . " There was a short silence , broken only by the whispering of the wind in the fir trees . Then on the stillness came a light , rippling laugh . [Dodo]79-dodo got out of [her]79-dodo chair , and plucked a couple of roses from a bush near [her]79-dodo . "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't be serious any longer , " [she]79-dodo said ; "[0-i] not a single moment longer . [I]0-i 'm so dreadfully glad to be in [England]1-england again . Really , there is no place like [it]1-england . [I]0-i hate the insolent extravagant beauty of [Switzerland]58-switzerland ‚Äî it is like chromo lithographs . Look at [that long , flat , grey distance over there]1792-that long , flat , grey distance over there . There is nothing so beautiful as [that abroad]1793-that abroad . " [Dodo]79-dodo fastened the roses in the front of [her]79-dodo dress , and laughed again . "[0-i] [I]0-i laugh for pure happiness , " [she]79-dodo continued . "[0-i] [I]0-i laughed when [I]0-i saw [the cliff of [Dover]65-dover]1794-the cliff of dover to - day , not because [I]0-i was sea - sick ‚Äî [I]0-i never am sea - sick ‚Äî but simply because [I]0-i was coming [home]282-home again . [Jack]78-jack parted from [me]0-i at [Dover]65-dover . [I]0-i am very happy about [Jack]78-jack . [I]0-i believe in [him]78-jack thoroughly . " [Dodo]79-dodo was getting serious again in spite of [herself]79-dodo . [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham was watching [her]79-dodo curiously , and without any feeling of disappointment . [She]191-lady grantham did not wear spectacles , [she]191-lady grantham was , at least , as tall as [herself]191-lady grantham , and [she]191-lady grantham dressed , if anything , rather better . [She]191-lady grantham was still wearing half - mourning , but half - mourning suited [Dodo]79-dodo very well . "[0-i] Decidedly it 's a pity to analyse [one]2148-one 's feelings , " [Dodo]79-dodo went on , "[0-i] they do resolve themselves into such very small factors . [I]0-i am well , [I]0-i am in [England]1-england , where [you]1797-your can eat [your]1797-your dinner without suspicion of frogs , or caterpillars in [your]1797-your cauliflower . [I]0-i had two caterpillars in [my]0-i cauliflower at [Zermatt]51-zermatt one night . [I]0-i shall sleep in a clean white bed , and [I]0-i shall not have to use [Keating]225-keating . [I]0-i can talk as ridiculously as [I]0-i like , without thinking of [the French]226-the french for anything . Oh , [I]0-i 'm entirely happy . " [Dodo]79-dodo was aware of more reasons for happiness than [she]79-dodo mentioned . [She]79-dodo was particularly conscious of the relief [she]79-dodo felt in getting away from [the Prince]2616-the prince . For some days past [she]79-dodo had been unpleasantly aware of [his]2616-the prince presence . [She]79-dodo could not manage to think of [him]2616-the prince quite as lightly as [she]79-dodo thought of [anyone else]342-anyone else . It was a continual effort to [her]79-dodo to appear quite [herself]79-dodo in [his]2616-the prince presence , and [she]79-dodo was constantly rushing into extremes in order to seem at [her]79-dodo ease . [He]2616-the prince was stronger , [she]79-dodo felt , than [she]79-dodo was , and [she]79-dodo did not like it . The immense relief which [his]2616-the prince absence brought more than compensated for the slight blankness that [his]2616-the prince absence left . In a way [she]79-dodo felt dependent on [him]2616-the prince , which chafed and irritated [her]79-dodo , for [she]79-dodo had never come under such a yoke before . [She]79-dodo had had several moments of sudden anger against [herself]79-dodo on [her]79-dodo way [home]282-home . [She]79-dodo found [herself]79-dodo always thinking about [him]2616-the prince when [she]79-dodo was not thinking about anything else ; and though [she]79-dodo was quite capable of sending [her]79-dodo thoughts off to other subjects , when [they]3057-they had done [their]3057-they work [they]3057-they always fluttered back again to the same resting - place , and [Dodo]79-dodo was conscious of an effort , slight indeed , but still an effort , in frightening [them]3057-they off . [Her]79-dodo curious insistence on [her]79-dodo own happiness had struck [Edith]104-edith . [She]104-edith felt it unnatural that [Dodo]79-dodo should mention it , and [she]104-edith drew one of two conclusions from it ; either that [Dodo]79-dodo had had a rather trying time , for some reason or other , or that [she]104-edith wished to convince [herself]104-edith , by constant repetition , of something that [she]104-edith was not quite sure about ; and both of these conclusions were in a measure correct . " "[0-i] Oh , yes , " said [Dodo]79-dodo ; "[0-i] a little ponderous , [you]0-i know , but very presentable , and good company . " [Edith]104-edith looked up suddenly at [Dodo]79-dodo . There was an elaborate carelessness , [she]104-edith thought , in [her]104-edith voice . It was just a little overdone . The night was descending fast , and [she]104-edith could only just see the lines of [her]104-edith face above the misty folds of [her]104-edith grey dress . But even in that half light [she]104-edith thought that [her]104-edith careless voice did not quite seem a true interpretation of [her]104-edith expression . It might have been only the dimness of the shadow , but [she]104-edith thought [she]104-edith looked anxious and rather depressed . [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham drew [her]191-lady grantham shawl more closely round [her]191-lady grantham shoulders , and remarked that it was getting cold . [Edith]104-edith got up and prepared to go in , and [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham nestled in [her]105-miss grantham chair . Only [Dodo]79-dodo stood quite motionless , and [Edith]104-edith noticed that [her]104-edith hands were tearing one of the roses to pieces , and scattering the petals on the grass . " "[79-dodo] [I]0-i think [Dodo]79-dodo must be tired or something , " said [Edith]104-edith . "[79-dodo] [I]0-i never saw [her]79-dodo like that before . [She]79-dodo was horribly serious . [I]0-i hope nothing has happened . " The piano in [the drawing - room]338-the drawing - room was close to a large French window opening on to [the lawn]2840-the lawn . [Edith]104-edith threw it open , and stood for a moment looking out into the darkness . [She]104-edith could just see [Dodo]79-dodo and [Nora]192-nora sitting where [they]1811-they had left [them]1811-they , though [they]1811-they were no more than two pale spots against the dark background . [She]104-edith was conscious of a strange feeling that there was an undercurrent at work in [Dodo]79-dodo , which showed itself by a few chance bubbles and little sudden eddies on the surface , which [she]104-edith thought required explanation . [Dodo]79-dodo certainly was not quite like [herself]79-dodo . There was no edge to [her]79-dodo vivacity : [her]79-dodo attempts not to be serious had been distinctly forced , and [she]79-dodo was unable to keep it up . [Edith]104-edith felt a vague sense of coming disaster ; slight but certain . However , [she]104-edith drew [her]104-edith chair to the piano and began to play . [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham was conscious of the same sort of feeling . Since [the others]2202-the others had gone in , [Dodo]79-dodo had sat quite silent , and [she]79-dodo had not taken [her]79-dodo cigarette . "[79-dodo] [You]1812-you had a nice time then , abroad ? " [she]79-dodo remarked at length . "[1812-you] Oh , yes , " said [Dodo]79-dodo , rousing [herself]79-dodo . "[1812-you] [I]0-i enjoyed it a good deal . " "[2616-the prince] Ah , [you]1812-you think that , do [you]1812-you ? " asked [Dodo]79-dodo , with the most careful carelessness . "[1812-you] [He]2616-the prince struck [me]0-i that way , too , a little . " "[2616-the prince] [I]0-i should think [he]2616-the prince was an instance of what [Edith]104-edith meant when [she]104-edith said that to be intimate with [anyone]343-anyone was to be under [their]343-anyone influence . " "[104-edith] [Edith]104-edith 's awfully wrong , [I]0-i think , about the whole idea , " said [Dodo]79-dodo , hastily . "[0-i] [I]0-i should hate to be under [anyone]343-anyone 's influence ; yet , [I]0-i think , the only pleasure of knowing [people]308-people is to be intimate . [I]0-i would sooner have [one real friend]1821-one real friend than [fifty acquaintances]1822-fifty acquaintances . " "[1822-fifty acquaintances] Did [you]1812-you see much of [him]2616-the prince ? The worst of it is , the Venus part is so much more attractive than the other . It 's horrible . " "[0-i] [You]0-i 're dreadfully serious to - night , [Dodo]79-dodo , " said [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm a little tired , [I]0-i think , " [she]105-miss grantham said . "[0-i] [I]0-i was travelling all last night , [you]0-i know . Come , let 's go in . " [Dodo]79-dodo went to bed soon afterwards . [She]79-dodo said [she]79-dodo was tired , and a little overdone . [Edith]104-edith looked at [her]79-dodo rather closely as [she]104-edith said good - night . "[0-i] [You]0-i 're sure it 's nothing more ? " [she]104-edith asked . "[0-i] There 's nothing wrong with [you]0-i , is there ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i shall be all right in the morning , " said [Dodo]79-dodo , rather wearily . "[0-i] Do n't let [them]1824-them call [me]0-i till nine . " [Dodo]79-dodo went [upstairs]337-upstairs and found that [[her]79-dodo maid]2947-her maid had unpacked for [her]79-dodo . A heap of books was lying on the table , and from among these [she]79-dodo drew out a large envelope with a photograph inside . It was signed "[155-prince waldenech] [Waldenech]155-prince waldenech . " [Dodo]79-dodo looked at it a moment , then placed it back in its envelope , and went to the window . [She]79-dodo felt the necessity of air . [The room]339-the room seemed close and hot , and [she]79-dodo threw it wide open . [She]79-dodo stood there for ten minutes or more quite still , looking out into the night . Then [she]79-dodo went back to the table and took up the envelope again . With a sudden passionate gesture [she]79-dodo tore it in half , then across again , and threw the pieces into the grate . [Dodo]79-dodo slept long and dreamlessly that night ; the deep , dreamless sleep which an evenly - balanced fatigue of body and mind so often produces , though [we]3065-our get into bed feeling that [our]3065-our brain is too deep in some tangle of unsolved thought to be able to extricate itself , and fall into the dim immensity of sleep . The waking from such a sleep is not so pleasant . The first moment of conscious thought sometimes throws the whole burden again on to [our]3065-our brain with a sudden start of pain that is almost physical . There is no transition . [We]3065-our were asleep and [we]3065-our are awake , and [we]3065-our find that sleep has brought [us]3065-our only a doubtful gift , for with [our]3065-our renewed strength of body has come the capability of keener suffering . When [we]3065-our are tired , mental distress is only a dull ache , but in the hard , convincing morning it strikes a deadlier and deeper pain . But sometimes Nature is more merciful . [She]79-dodo opens the sluices of [our]3065-our brain quietly , and , though the water still rushes in turbidly and roughly , yet the fact that [our]3065-our brain fills by degrees makes [us]3065-our more able to bear the full weight , than when it comes suddenly with a wrenching and , perhaps , a rending of [our]3065-our mental machinery . It was in this way that [Dodo]79-dodo woke . The trouble of the day came to [her]79-dodo gradually during the moments of waking . [She]79-dodo dreamed [she]79-dodo was waiting for [Jack]78-jack in [the garden where [she]79-dodo had been sitting the night before]3066-the garden where she had been sitting the night before . It was perfectly dark , and [she]79-dodo could not see [him]78-jack coming , but [she]79-dodo heard a step along [the gravel path]3067-the gravel path , and started up with a vague alarm , for it did not sound like [his]78-jack . Then a greyness , as of dawn , began to steal over the night , and [she]79-dodo saw the outline of the trees against the sky , and the outline of [a man]279-a man 's figure near [her]79-dodo , and it was a figure [she]79-dodo knew well , but it was not [Jack]78-jack . On this dream the sense of waking was pure relief ; it was broad day , and [[her]79-dodo maid]2947-her maid was standing by [her]79-dodo and saying that it was a quarter past nine . [Dodo]79-dodo lay still a few moments longer , feeling a vague joy that [her]79-dodo dream was not true , that the helplessness of that grey moment , when [she]79-dodo saw that it was not [Jack]78-jack , was passed , that [she]79-dodo was awake again , and unfettered , save by thoughts which could be consciously checked and stifled . It was with a vast sense of satisfaction that [she]79-dodo remembered [her]79-dodo last act on the evening before , of which the scattered fragments in the grate afforded ocular proof . [She]79-dodo felt as if [she]79-dodo had broken a visible , tangible fetter ‚Äî one strand , at any rate , of the cord that hound [her]79-dodo was lying broken before [her]79-dodo eyes . If [she]79-dodo had been quite securely tied [she]79-dodo could not have done that .. ‚Äî The sense of successful effort , with a visible result , gave [her]79-dodo a sudden feeling of power to do more ; the absence of bodily fatigue , and the presence of superfluous physical health , all seemed part of a different order of things to that of the night before . [She]79-dodo got up and dressed quickly , feeling more like [her]79-dodo own self than [she]79-dodo had done for several days . The destruction of [his]78-jack photograph was really a great achievement . [She]79-dodo had no idea how far things had gone till [she]79-dodo felt the full effect of conscious effort and its result . [She]79-dodo could see now exactly where [she]79-dodo had stood on the evening before , very unpleasantly close to the edge of [a nasty place]3070-a nasty place , slippery and steep . Anyhow , [she]79-dodo was one step nearer [that pleasant , green - looking spot at the top of the slope]3071-that pleasant , green - looking spot at the top of the slope ‚Äî [a quiet , pretty place , not particularly extensive , but very pleasing , and very safe]3072-a quiet , pretty place , not particularly extensive , but very pleasing , and very safe . [The three others]3073-the three others were half - way through breakfast when [Dodo]79-dodo came down . [Lady Grantham]191-lady grantham was feeling a little bored . " [Dodo]79-dodo had quite forgotten that [she]79-dodo had intended to go for a ride , and [she]79-dodo went into [the garden]2812-the garden with [Nora]192-nora , and played ducks and drakes on [the pond]3081-the pond , and punted [herself]79-dodo about , and gathered water - lilies . Then [she]79-dodo was seized with an irresistible desire to fish , and caught a large pike , which refused to be killed , and [Dodo]79-dodo had to fetch [the gardener]3082-the gardener to slay it . [She]79-dodo then talked an astonishing amount of perfect nonsense , and thought that it must be lunch - time . Accordingly , [she]79-dodo went back to [the house]2114-the house , and was found by [Edith]104-edith , a quarter of an hour later , playing hide - and - seek with [[the coachman]3084-the coachman 's children]3085-the coachman 's children , whom [she]79-dodo had lured in from [the stable - yard]3086-the stable - yard as [she]79-dodo went by . [The two seekers]3089-the two seekers entirely declined to consider that [she]79-dodo had won , and [Dodo]79-dodo , with a show of reason , was telling [them]3089-the two seekers that [they]3089-the two seekers had n't caught [her]79-dodo yet at any rate . " [She]79-dodo met [the man]520-the man walking back to [the house]2114-the house , having looked for [her]79-dodo in vain . [She]79-dodo took the telegram and opened it . [Dodo]79-dodo experienced , in epitome at that moment , all [she]79-dodo had gone through the night before . " [She]79-dodo handed it to [the man]520-the man , and gave orders that it should go at once . [Dodo]79-dodo did not move . [She]79-dodo sat still with [her]79-dodo hands clasped in front of [her]79-dodo , unconscious of active thought , only knowing that a stream of pictures seemed to pass before [her]79-dodo eyes . " The idea of [the Prince]2616-the prince waiting at [Dover]65-dover was distinctly amusing , and [Dodo]79-dodo found a broad smile to bestow on the thought before [she]79-dodo continued examining the state of [her]79-dodo feelings and position . The Prince 's influence over [her]79-dodo [she]79-dodo felt was local and personal , so to speak , and now [she]79-dodo had made [her]79-dodo decision , [she]79-dodo was surprised at the ease with which it had been made . Had [he]2616-the prince been there in person , with [his]2616-the prince courtly presence and [his]2616-the prince serene remoteness from anything ordinary , and had said , in that smooth , well - modulated , voice , "[1871-the telegraph boys] May [I]0-i hope to find [you]1872-you in to - morrow ? " [Dodo]79-dodo felt that [she]79-dodo would have said "[0-i] Come . " [Her]79-dodo pride was in frantic rebellion at these admissions ; even the telegram [she]79-dodo had sent was a confession of weakness . [She]79-dodo would not see [him]2616-the prince , because [she]79-dodo was afraid . Was there any other reason ? [she]79-dodo asked [herself]79-dodo . Yes ; [she]79-dodo could not see [him]2616-the prince because [she]79-dodo longed to see [him]2616-the prince . "[0-i] Has it come to that ? " [she]79-dodo thought , as [she]79-dodo crumpled up the telegram which had fluttered down from [her]79-dodo lap on to the grass . [Dodo]79-dodo felt [she]79-dodo was quite unnecessarily honest with [herself]79-dodo in making this admission . But what followed ? Nothing followed . [She]79-dodo was going to marry [Jack]78-jack , and be remarkably happy , and [Prince Waldenech]155-prince waldenech should come and stay with [them]3108-them because [she]79-dodo liked [him]2616-the prince very much , and [she]79-dodo would be delightfully kind to [him]2616-the prince , and [Jack]78-jack should like [him]2616-the prince too . [Dear old Jack]78-jack , [she]79-dodo would write [him]2616-the prince a line this minute , saying when [she]79-dodo would be back in [London]2-london . [Dodo]79-dodo felt a sudden spasm of anger against [the Prince]2616-the prince . What right had [he]2616-the prince to behave like this ? [He]2616-the prince was making it very hard for [her]79-dodo , and [he]2616-the prince would get nothing by it . [Her]79-dodo decision was irrevocable ; [she]79-dodo would not see [him]2616-the prince again , for some time at any rate . [She]79-dodo would get over this ridiculous fear of [him]2616-the prince . What was [he]2616-the prince that [other men]2285-other men were not ? What was the position , after all ? [He]2616-the prince had wanted to marry [her]79-dodo ; [she]79-dodo had refused [him]2616-the prince because [she]79-dodo was engaged to [Jack]78-jack . If there had been no [Jack]78-jack ‚Äî well , there was [a Jack]3111-a jack , so it was unnecessary to pursue that any further . [He]2616-the prince had given [her]79-dodo [his]2616-the prince photograph , and had said several things that [he]2616-the prince should not have said . [Dodo]79-dodo thought of that scene with regret . [She]79-dodo had had an opportunity which [she]79-dodo had missed ; [she]79-dodo might easily have made it plain to [him]2616-the prince that [his]2616-the prince murmured speeches went beyond mere courtesy . Instead of that [she]79-dodo had said [she]79-dodo would always regard [him]2616-the prince as [a great friend]3112-a great friend , and hoped [he]2616-the prince would see [her]79-dodo often . [She]79-dodo tapped the ground impatiently as [she]79-dodo thought of missed opportunities . It was stupid , inconceivably stupid of [her]79-dodo . Then [he]2616-the prince had followed [her]79-dodo to [England]1-england , and sent this telegram . [She]79-dodo did not feel safe . [She]79-dodo longed , and dreaded to see [him]2616-the prince again . It was too absurd that [she]79-dodo should have to play this gigantic game of hide - and - seek . "[0-i] [I]0-i shall have to put on a blue veil and green goggles when [I]0-i go back to [London]2-london , " thought [Dodo]79-dodo . "[0-i] Well , [the seekers]1873-the seekers have to catch [the hiders]3088-the hiders , and [he]3088-the hiders has n't caught [me]0-i yet . " Meanwhile [the Prince]2616-the prince was smoking a cigar at [Dover Station]71-dover station . The telegram had not come , though [he]2616-the prince had waited an hour , and [he]2616-the prince had settled to give it another half - hour and then go on to [London]2-london . [He]2616-the prince was not at all angry ; it was as good as a game of chess . [The Prince]155-prince waldenech was very fond of chess . [He]155-prince waldenech enjoyed exercising a calculating long - sightedness , and [he]155-prince waldenech felt that [the Marchioness of Chesterford elect]3114-the marchioness of chesterford elect was a problem that enabled [him]155-prince waldenech to exercise this faculty , of which [he]155-prince waldenech had plenty , to the full . [He]155-prince waldenech had a sublime sense of certainty as to what [he]155-prince waldenech was going to do . [He]155-prince waldenech fully intended to marry [Dodo]79-dodo , and [he]155-prince waldenech admitted no obstacles . [She]79-dodo was engaged to [Jack]78-jack , was [she]79-dodo ? So much the worse for [Jack]78-jack . [She]79-dodo wished to marry [Jack]78-jack , did [she]79-dodo ? So much the worse for [her]79-dodo , and none the worse , possibly the better , for [him]78-jack . As it was quite certain that [he]155-prince waldenech [himself]155-prince waldenech was going to marry [Dodo]79-dodo , these little hitches were entertaining than otherwise . It is more fun to catch [your]3115-your salmon after a quarter of an hour 's rather exciting fight with [him]78-jack than to net [him]78-jack . Half the joy of a possession lies in the act of acquisition , and the pleasure of acquisition consists , at least in half of the excitement attendant on it . To say that [the Prince]2616-the prince ever regarded [anyone]343-anyone 's feelings would be understating the truth . The fact that [his]155-prince waldenech will worked its way in opposition to , and at the expense of [others]299-others , afforded [him]155-prince waldenech a distinct and appreciable pleasure . If [he]155-prince waldenech wanted anything [he]155-prince waldenech went straight for it , and regarded [neither man]3119-neither man , nor devil , nor angel ; and [he]155-prince waldenech wanted [Dodo]79-dodo . [His]155-prince waldenech mind , then , was thoroughly made up . [She]79-dodo seemed to [him]155-prince waldenech immensely original and very complete . [He]155-prince waldenech read [her]79-dodo , [he]155-prince waldenech thought , like a book , and the book was very interesting reading . [His]155-prince waldenech sending of the telegram with "[3088-the hiders] Reply paid , " was a positive stroke of genius . [Dodo]79-dodo had told [him]155-prince waldenech that [she]79-dodo was going straight to [London]2-london , but , as [we]3120-we have seen , [she]79-dodo did not stop the night there , but went straight on to [[Edith]104-edith 's home in [Berkshire]72-berkshire]3121-edith 's home in berkshire . There were two courses open to [her]79-dodo ; either to reply "[3088-the hiders] Yes " or "[3088-the hiders] No " to the telegram , or to leave it unanswered . If [she]79-dodo left it "[3088-the hiders] unanswered " it would delight [him]155-prince waldenech above measure , and it seemed that [his]155-prince waldenech wishes were to be realised . Not answering the telegram would imply that [she]79-dodo did not think good to see [him]155-prince waldenech , and [he]155-prince waldenech judged that this decision was probably prompted by something deeper than mere indifference to [his]155-prince waldenech company . It must be dictated by a strong motive . [His]155-prince waldenech calculations were a little at fault , because [Dodo]79-dodo had not stopped in [London]2-london , but this made no difference , as events had turned out , to the correctness of [his]155-prince waldenech deductions . [He]155-prince waldenech very much wished [Dodo]79-dodo to be influenced by strong motives in [her]79-dodo dealings with [him]155-prince waldenech . [He]155-prince waldenech would not have accepted , even as a gift , the real , quiet liking [she]79-dodo had for [Jack]78-jack . Real , quiet likings seemed to [him]155-prince waldenech to be as dull as total indifference . [He]155-prince waldenech would not have objected to [her]79-dodo regarding [him]155-prince waldenech with violent loathing , that would be something to correct ; and [his]155-prince waldenech experience in such affairs was that strong sympathies and antipathies were more akin to each other than quiet affection or an apathetic indifference were to either . [He]155-prince waldenech walked up and down [the platform]3122-the platform with the smile of [a man who is waiting for an interesting situation in a theatrical representation to develop itself]3123-a man who is waiting for an interesting situation in a theatrical representation to develop itself . [Two men]1911-two men quarrel about [a woman]323-a woman . [They]1911-two men both make love to [her]323-a woman ; in other words , [they]1911-two men both try to cut each other 's throats , and one succeeds . It is far more sensible . [Pistols]236-pistols are stupid bull - headed weapons . Words are much finer . They are exquisite sharp daggers . There is no unnecessary noise or smoke , and they are quite orderly . " "[79-dodo] Are those the weapons [you]0-i would fight [Lord Chesterford]80-chesterford with , if [Dodo]79-dodo told [you]0-i to ? " asked [Edith]104-edith , who was growing uneasy . [Jack]78-jack would not speak to [you]79-dodo . " [Dodo]79-dodo felt strongly the necessity of putting an end to this conversation , which was effectually done by this somewhat uncourteous speech . "[2902-the princess] [I]0-i believe [you]1927-you can even get blas√© of being bored , " said [Miss Grantham]105-miss grantham , "[0-i] and then , of course , [you]1927-you do n't get bored any longer , because [you]1927-you are bored with it . " This remarkable statement was instantly contradicted by [Edith]104-edith . "[1927-you] Being bored is a bottomless pit , " [she]104-edith remarked . "[1927-you] [You]1927-you never get to the end , and the deeper [you]1927-you go the longer it takes to get out . [I]0-i was never bored in [my]0-i life . ' " [Dodo]79-dodo was conscious of talking rather wildly and incoherently . " "[79-dodo] [Dodo]79-dodo shook hands with elaborate carelessness and went towards the door , which [the Prince]2616-the prince opened for [her]79-dodo . "[2616-the prince] [Dodo]79-dodo went [upstairs]337-upstairs into [[her]79-dodo bedroom]1963-her bedroom . [Dodo]79-dodo was up again in [London]2-london at the end of the week , as [she]79-dodo had told [the Prince]2616-the prince . [Jack]78-jack was also staying in [town]513-town , and [they]1972-they often spent most of the day together ; riding occasionally in [the deserted Row]1973-the deserted row , or sitting , as [they]1972-they were now , in [[Dodo]79-dodo 's room in [the Eaton Square house]1975-the eaton square house]1974-dodo 's room in the eaton square house . [They]1972-they were both leaving for [the country]2090-the country in a few days ' time , where [they]1972-they had arranged to come across [one another]1006-one another at [various houses]1978-various houses , and [Dodo]79-dodo , at least , was finding these few days rather trying . [She]79-dodo and [Jack]78-jack had arranged to have [them]1972-they together , quite alone , while [they]1972-they were in [Switzerland]58-switzerland , and [Dodo]79-dodo had overlooked the fact that they might be rather hard to fill up . Not that [she]79-dodo was disappointed in [Jack]78-jack . [He]78-jack was exactly what [she]79-dodo had always supposed [him]78-jack to be . [She]79-dodo never thought that [he]78-jack was very stimulating , though never dull , and [she]79-dodo was quite conscious of enough stimulus in [herself]79-dodo for that . For the rest [he]78-jack was quite satisfactory . But [she]79-dodo was distinctly disappointed in [herself]79-dodo . [She]79-dodo felt as if [her]79-dodo taste had been vitiated by drinking brandy . Mild flavours and very good bouquets of vintages that had pleased [her]79-dodo before , sent no message from [her]79-dodo palate to [her]79-dodo brain . It was like the effect produced by the touch of hot iron on the skin , that forms a hard numb surface , which is curiously insensitive to touch . [Dodo]79-dodo felt as if [her]79-dodo powers of sensation had been seared in this way . [Her]79-dodo perceptions no longer answered quickly to the causes that excited them ; a layer of dull , unresponsive material lay between [her]79-dodo and [[her]79-dodo world]1979-her world . [She]79-dodo thought that [her]79-dodo nerves and tissues were sound enough below . This numbness was only superficial , the burn would heal , and [her]79-dodo skin would become pliant and soft again ; and if [she]79-dodo was conscious of all this and its corresponding causes , it could hardly be expected that [Jack]78-jack would be unconscious of it and its corresponding effects . On this particular morning [Dodo]79-dodo was particularly aware of it . It was raining dismally outside , and the sky was heavy and grey . [The road]257-the road was being repaired , and a traction engine was performing its dismal office in little aimless runs backwards and forwards . [The official with a red flag]1981-the official with a red flag had found there were no vehicles for [him]1981-the official with a red flag to warn and [he]1981-the official with a red flag had sat down on a heap of stones , and was smoking . There was a general air of stagnation , a sense of the futility of doing anything , and [no one]2046-no one was more conscious of it than [Dodo]79-dodo . [She]79-dodo felt that there was only one event that was likely to interest [her]79-dodo , and yet , in a way , [she]79-dodo shrank from that . It was the searing process over again . [She]79-dodo wondered whether it would do any good to tell [Jack]78-jack of the fact that [the Prince]2616-the prince was down at [Wokingham]74-wokingham . [She]79-dodo found the burden of an unshared secret exceptionally trying . [Dodo]79-dodo had been so accustomed to be before the footlights all [her]79-dodo life , that anything of the nature of a secret was oppressive . [Her]79-dodo conduct to [[her]79-dodo first husband]1984-her first husband [she]79-dodo did not regard as such . It was only an admirable piece of by - play , which [the audience]1985-the audience fully appreciated . Did [Dodo]79-dodo then never think of [[her]79-dodo late husband]1986-her late husband with tenderness ? Well , not often . A thought seldom remained long in [Dodo]79-dodo 's mind without finding expression . [She]79-dodo turned round suddenly . When [Jack]78-jack caught [her]79-dodo up [she]79-dodo was [herself]79-dodo again , and described how a selection of [Edith]104-edith 's dogs had kept [the postman]1988-the postman at bay one morning , until the unusual absence of barking and howling had led [[their]1987-they mistress]309-their mistress to further investigations , which were rewarded by finding [the postman]1988-the postman sitting in [the boat - house]1991-the boat - house , and defending [himself]1988-the postman with the punt pole . [Jack]78-jack was singularly easy - going , and very trustful , and [he]78-jack did not bother [his]78-jack head any more about it at the time . But [we]1992-we have to attain an almost unattainable dominion over [our]1992-we minds to prevent thoughts suddenly starting up in front of [us]1992-we . When a thought has occurred to one , it is a matter of training and practice to encourage or dismiss it , but the other is beyond the reach of [the general]1993-the general . And as [Dodo]79-dodo finished these last words , [Jack]78-jack found [himself]78-jack suddenly face to face with a new thought . It was so new that it startled [him]78-jack , and [he]78-jack looked at it again .
